title: Multiple camera instances problem -  "Android camera encountered a problem.."
body:
Opening multiple camera instances will result with Android camera problem on android 7.1.1 - Samsung J5 device.
`Sorry, the Android camera encountered a problem. You may need to restart the device.`

If mentioned problem occurs, user needs to restart device to continue with normal camera work (also native camera not working).

**Note**: Zxing Scanner app is opening as external app from my own application, it is not integrated.

Steps to reproduce:
- open `example` custom app - and choose scan using zxing scanner (zxing scanner app is opened external)
- minimize `example` app
- open Zxing Scanner app directly

**Note2** if error not occurs at first time, try to mix these steps few times, I am able to produce it every time.

Device: Samsung J5 (same bug on multiple devices)
Android: 7.1.1

title: Continue in codeset A when character encoded single number or FNC1-4 in Code128Writer
body:
The string `"\n\u00f4\n" (LF FNC4 LF)` should be encoded to:
`START_CODE_A + LF + FNC4A + LF + checksum + STOP`
but got:
`START_CODE_A + LF + SWITCH_CODE_B + FNC4B + SWITCH_CODE_A + LF + checksum + STOP`.

It should be able to continue in codeset A when character encoded FNC4.
Also single number and FNC1-3 are continuable.

title: ByQuadrantReader NullPointerException
body:
`LuminanceSource source = new BufferedImageLuminanceSource(bufferredImage);`
`BinaryBitmap bitmap = new BinaryBitmap(new HybridBinarizer(source));`
`ByQuadrantReader byQuadrantReader = new ByQuadrantReader(reader);`
`GenericMultipleBarcodeReader multiReader = new GenericMultipleBarcodeReader(byQuadrantReader);`
`Result[] results = multiReader.decodeMultiple(bitmap);`

Here on decodeMultiple(bitmap) a NullPointerException is thrown.
Its from Line num 110 in  [https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/multi/ByQuadrantReader.java](url) .

Downloaded source code and updated it to do a simple Null check before going in. It seems to work.

title: On some older phones the app crashes with an error after 5 to 20 scans
body:
Hi,

I'm using the ZXing app for scanning and after the last update some of my older phones get an error after about 5 to 20 scans. It is the message "Sorry, the Android camera encountered a problem. You may need to restart the device" The only solution is indeed restarting the phone.

Error occurs on three Samsung S3 phones and one Samsung J3 phone.

Other phones do not have the issue. 
If I reinstall com.google.zxing.client.android-4.7.3-103-minAPI15.apk it all works again for all phones.
Not much to go on, but I hope you can fix this...


Regards,
Frank

title: Rewrite DataMatrix Detector
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
In DataMatrixBlackBox2TestCase, only 8 of 18 images can read without rotation.
So I rewrote the detector and got better score.

Main idea of this PR is moving the corner points to near the center of the corner modules
because detecting transitions on the edge is not stable.

title: Corrected exception message in UPCEWriter
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body: I am still porting commits to the ZXingObjC project. As I read through the code, I believe I found a small mistake: according to EAN13Writer, both possibilities (7 or 8 digits) should be reflected within the message.

title: Corrected exception message in EAN8Writer
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body: I am still porting commits to the ZXingObjC project. As I read through the code, I believe I found a small mistake: according to EAN13Writer, both possibilities (7 or 8 digits) should be reflected within the message.

title: 解压根本打不开
body:
(Please remove this text once you've read and understood it.)

## Contributing

The project is in maintenance mode, meaning, changes are driven by contributed patches.
There is otherwise no active development or roadmap for this project. It is "DIY".

Only proposed changes in the form of a pull request are likely to be acted on, but,
these will be acted on promptly.

### Questions

Questions should be asked on the mailing list:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zxing

### Feature Requests

Feature requests are not accepted and will generally be closed.
Feature requests with a pull request may be accepted. When in doubt, discuss on the
mailing list first.

### Bug Reports

Bug reports must have enough detail to understand and reproduce the problem. Inadequate
bug reports will be closed with a request for more information.

Bug reports without an associated pull request are not likely to be addressed, but will be
left open for some time to see if anyone can contribute a solution. However, bug reports
with a pull request are likely to be merged promptly.

Support for QR Code Model 1

In a project I recently worked on, we needed to scan some old QR codes (Model 1) as specified in ISO 18004:2000 Annex M. Due to the existing code base here, the implementation was rather straight forward.
Is there any interest in including it? (So far, only #156 and some old posts on the mailing list mention it.) If so, I would clean up my patchset and prepare a pull-request.

title: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs (CWE ID 117) (CRLF Injection)
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
**### Bug Reports**

We are using Zxing library (com.google.zxing:core: 3.3.3) on our project. And We did Vera Code (Ref: https://www.veracode.com ) Scan to find out the flaws and fix them. And We got the Improper Output Neutralization for Logs (CWE ID 117) (CRLF Injection) flaws on DecodeHintManager.java (Line Number: 227). It is producing by writing untrusted data into a log file allows an attacker to forge log entries or inject malicious content into log files.

**Current Code, which produce this flaw**
Log.w(TAG, "Ignoring hint " + hintType + " because it is not assignable from " + hintData);

**Recommendations**
Avoid directly embedding user input in log files when possible. Sanitize untrusted data used to construct log entries by using a safe logging mechanism such as the OWASP ESAPI Logger, which will automatically remove unexpected carriage returns and line feeds and can be configured to use HTML entity encoding for non-alphanumeric data. Only write custom blacklisting code when absolutely necessary. Always validate untrusted input to ensure that it conforms to the expected format, using centralized data validation routines when possible.  (Taking reference from Vera Code Scan Report Recommendation). 

Can you guys please help to fix this issue ? I know, we can use the temporary Mitigation action (https://help.veracode.com/reader/DGHxSJy3Gn3gtuSIN2jkRQ/~p4MSKOS8F8X8h0KwFTKoQ) But I think, this is not good idea to avoid the issue instead of fix, if possible. Thanks!

title: Abuse of unicode can lead to very convincing phishing links
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="bug")]
body:
Hi, I just wanted to let you know that your scanner doesn't do a good job of handling unicode, which leads to some nasty possibilities around malicious links. For instance, here's two screenshots, both of which lead to my site if clicked:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1331014/43690692-4eca42d6-98c3-11e8-9a4d-28b32f7a54a4.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1331014/43690693-51fac02a-98c3-11e8-8120-ad5cb6913a4f.png)

The first link is abusing an RTL character and is actually
(\u202e)https://dylankatz.com/moc.elgoog.www
This can be fixed by replacing whitespace unicode characters with spaces.

The second link abuses a character that looks like a slash and is actually:
http://www.google.xn--comsearchquery-iu3hgf.dktz.co
when rendered to punycode

title: Directory Bug
body: The correct pattern to make a directory is: `if (!dir.mkdirs() && !dir.isDirectory()) { error }` mkdirs checks for exists so the exists check is redundant.

title: Directory Bug
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body: The correct pattern to make a directory is: `if (!dir.mkdirs() && !dir.isDirectory()) { error }` mkdirs checks for exists so the exists check is redundant.

I've randomly stumbled upon this QR code (attached) and decided to scan it out of curiosity.

title: fix binary shift cost heuristics
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
This introduces some tests that show that the current heuristic that determines whether an encoding state can savely been dropped isn't valid for binary shift mode. That flaw may lead to inefficent encoding for non-textual data, i.e. the encoding uses some more bytes than the original octet encoding does.

It also comes with the fix for that heuristic.

title: Data Matrix  - using zxing.dll Interop VB Script  (Margin Issue)
body:
I just want to point out regarding data matrix - there is issue with 'margin' size for the output image.

here is the code I've used:

  qrCodeOptions.Height = 35
  qrCodeOptions.Width = 35
  qrCodeOptions.Margin = 0
  qrCodeOptions.PureBarcode = True
  qrCodeOptions.DefaultEncodation = ZXing.Datamatrix.Encoder.Encodation.ASCII
  qrCodeOptions.SymbolShape = ZXing.Datamatrix.Encoder.SymbolShapeHint.FORCE_SQUARE

title: Check if characters are digits for EAN_13, EAN_8, ITF and UPC_EAN_EXTENSION
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Several barcode formats only support digits 0-9, namely

- BarcodeFormat.EAN_13 
- BarcodeFormat.EAN_8 
- BarcodeFormat.ITF 
- BarcodeFormat.UPC_EAN_EXTENSION

Passing different characters to the encode function causes a runtime exception. 

**Proposed solution**
Check return value of Character.digit and throw IllegalArgumentException if it is -1 (invalid character.)
Source: https://developer.android.com/reference/java/lang/Character#digit(int,%20int)

title: Fix QR-code hanzi segment decoder
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:

The new value `0xA00` means `0xB0A1 - 0xA6A1`.

label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:

I found a bug that string of `GenericGFPoly(QR_CODE_FIELD_256, new int[] {3})` should be `"a^25"`, not `"3"`.

title: Optimize buffer size
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Optimize buffer size in `BitMatrix.xor()` and `BitArray.toString()`.

In BitMatrix.xor(), small buffer size causes allocation of BitArray every time in following loop.
(see BitMatrix.getRow)

BitArray change is just optimization.

title: Zxing _ Unity 3D _ Vuforia _ Camera lagging Issue
Set protocol to JABBER if XMPP IM handle is found
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
IMPP field can be set [to a URI][0]. If that URI is of XMPP scheme set the protocol used to JABBER and drop the scheme part from the IM handle.

This format is used by XMPP messengers e.g. [Conversations.im][1].

[0]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6350#section-6.4.3

[1]: https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/blob/master/README.md#how-does-the-address-book-integration-work

title: String utils tests
How to determine the decoder.decode() variables
body:
Hello all, as per the guidelines, I asked this question about a month ago [(here)](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/zxing/U6Xm1-uqpa4) but I have yet to hear a response so I wanted to repost it here. 

I am working with and relatively new to PDF417 images and am trying to decode them. I am utilizing the com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.decode() method [(link) ](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/04595508b63c3bde614b59dac361b50bfadb8757/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/pdf417/decoder/PDF417ScanningDecoder.java) and I see that the last 2 required parameters are: "int minCodewordWidth" and "int maxCodewordWidth".
Aside from the fact that I do not know how to obtain those, there is also a todo note up top that reads, "TODO don't pass in minCodewordWidth and maxCodewordWidth, pass in barcode columns for start and stop pattern columns".

At the time of this call, I have the bitmap image of the actual pdf417, the base64 String version of it, the BinaryBitmap, the ResultPoint array, and the PDF417DetectorResult(s). 

My question is, with the information I have, **how do I determine the required variables that are needed for this function**?

Thanks for the help, all!

title: aaa
body:
(Please remove this text once you've read and understood it.)

## Contributing

The project is in maintenance mode, meaning, changes are driven by contributed patches.
There is otherwise no active development or roadmap for this project. It is "DIY".

Only proposed changes in the form of a pull request are likely to be acted on, but,
these will be acted on promptly.

### Questions

Questions should be asked on the mailing list:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zxing

### Feature Requests

Feature requests are not accepted and will generally be closed.
Feature requests with a pull request may be accepted. When in doubt, discuss on the
mailing list first.

### Bug Reports

Bug reports must have enough detail to understand and reproduce the problem. Inadequate
bug reports will be closed with a request for more information.

Bug reports without an associated pull request are not likely to be addressed, but will be
left open for some time to see if anyone can contribute a solution. However, bug reports
with a pull request are likely to be merged promptly.

title: Unlicensed use of ZXing
body:
Hello ZXing team,

I just wanted to make you aware that the Waltonchain project (https://www.waltonchain.org/) is using your library without attribution.

The software 'WTCSetup1.17.exe" hosted here: https://github.com/WaltonChain/WaltonWallet_Win_x64

has been downloaded tens or hundreds of thousands of times, it is their node software and wallet.

While looking at the installed software, I became aware that they are using the code of no less than four separate software projects without obeying terms of licensing, even attribution.

Please let me know if I can assist in any way further.

title: Can't generate Aztec code when set EncodeHintType.ERROR_CORRECTION
Make integration of the core to 3rd party Android apps simpler
body:
Zxing has an Android app implemented in `android` submodule. It contains classes that might be used by other developers who want to implement a QR/bar code scanner in their apps. The simplest way to do it now is to copy sources of this sumbodule and modify them if needed. This is not very good as:

1. The submodule is quite big and contains a lot of sources (e.g. `PreferencesActivity`) that are unlikely to be needed in other apps

2. The submodule contains some code that is better to be shared as it is quite generic (e.g. `ViewfinderView`, `DecodeHintManager`, CameraConfigurationManager`) and might be updated in the future to workaround device specific bugs

To avoid this developers should be able to import only generic Android classes in their projects.

This pull request divides `android` classes into two groups: zxing-specific classes and generic classes. The latter are moved into `android-core` submodule and can be used by other developers via a simple dependency import.

title: Added a workaround for low framerate issue on Nexus 4
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Hi there,

Thanks for your great work!
I have tested ZXing on my Nexus 4 and found it suffers from a low frame rate issue. The camera is very slow and appears choppy on Nexus 4. Although it does not affect the major functionality but it still affects the usability.
I also found the following Stack Overflow discussions and adopted the workaround in this pull request.

Reference Stack Overflow Posts:
[Stack Overflow Post 1](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20252352/image-preview-is-very-slow-on-nexus4)
[Stack Overflow Post 2](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14131900/extreme-camera-lag-on-nexus-4)

Thanks! If you need further information, I may make a video to show the slow camera on Nexus 4.

title: Provide OSGi Metadata in Manifest
body:
To make it possible to use the lib without any extra work inside OSGi it would be good to include OSGi Metadata in the Manifest. Since this is ignored for no OSGi environments it wont disturb other users.

I'll provide a PR for this.

title: Using 'zxing' prefix for all generated artifacts
body:
The idea is to have a standard prefix for all _zxing_ artifacts so they don't conflict with existing ones (IMO) `core`, `javase`, `android` are too generic and might "collide" with others. Furthermore, the prefix makes it perfectly clear at a glance what is the function of the deployed JAR/WAR/artifact.

I am aware that this breaks backward compatibility in the sense that _Maven_ POM(s) using them will need to be updated, but in the long run I believe this is the correct way to go - see [Spring](https://spring.io/projects), [Hibernate](http://hibernate.org/) and others that use this convention.

P.S. I also removed the `<version>` where artifact version is same as the parent as it is the default _Maven_ behavior and also makes the POM(s) more robust since we avoid version duplication (a.k.a. the [D.R.Y. principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_repeat_yourself)). Note that I have left the special version override `4.7.7` in the _android_ POM.

title: Trailing and leading whitespace on GS1-128 when using FNC1 character
body:
I'm having a strange issue with the GS1-128 barcode.

When sending the barcode ```003425023080025013461003012018``` the barcode looks this way:
![ean128](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/844208/35389325-908a6b5c-01d7-11e8-873d-5b1894e5a6f3.jpg)

When sending the same barcode with the same parameters - but with the FNC1 character in it ```ñ00342502308002501346ñ1003012018``` - the barcode looks this way:
![gs1-128](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/844208/35389345-ab76bc54-01d7-11e8-8e3f-f4b3749264a6.jpg)

The system generates massive whitespace before and after the barcode.

Is this a bug or a feature? Can it be disabled?

```
Fatal Exception: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets
       at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.DecodedBitStreamParser.decode(DecodedBitStreamParser.java:96)
       at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.PDF417ScanningDecoder.decodeCodewords(PDF417ScanningDecoder.java:534)
```

title: Felix a
body:
(Please remove this text once you've read and understood it.)

## 

The project is in maintenance mode, meaning, changes are driven by contributed patches.
There is otherwise no active development or roadmap for this project. It is "DIY".

Only proposed changes in the form of a pull request are likely to be acted on, but,
these will be acted on promptly.

### Questions

Questions should be asked on the mailing list:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zxing

### Feature Requests

Feature requests are not accepted and will generally be closed.
Feature requests with a pull request may be accepted. When in doubt, discuss on the
mailing list first.

### Bug Reports

Bug reports must have enough detail to understand and reproduce the problem. Inadequate
bug reports will be closed with a request for more information.

Bug reports without an associated pull request are not likely to be addressed, but will be
left open for some time to see if anyone can contribute a solution. However, bug reports
with a pull request are likely to be merged promptly.

```

at android.app.ActivityThread.performResumeActivity(ActivityThread.java:2611)
at android.app.ActivityThread.handleResumeActivity(ActivityThread.java:2649)
at android.app.ActivityThread.handleLaunchActivity(ActivityThread.java:2122)
at android.app.ActivityThread.access$700(ActivityThread.java:134)
at android.app.ActivityThread$H.handleMessage(ActivityThread.java:1218)
at android.os.Handler.dispatchMessage(Handler.java:99)
at android.os.Looper.loop(Looper.java:137)
at android.app.ActivityThread.main(ActivityThread.java:4867)
at java.lang.reflect.Method.invokeNative(Native Method)
at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:511)
at com.android.internal.os.ZygoteInit$MethodAndArgsCaller.run(ZygoteInit.java:1007)
at com.android.internal.os.ZygoteInit.main(ZygoteInit.java:774)
at dalvik.system.NativeStart.main(Native Method)
```

Seems this was introduced in Android 4.4 - did not know zxing has a minSDK of 19 - usually the build of the app should break if a lib has a minSDK over the SDK of the app.

title: Add support for encoding GS1 formatted QR
body: This PR adds support for encoding GS1 formatted QR's through the addition of an encoding hint. Basically for the QR to meet the GS1 standard we must prefix the header bit stream with the FNC1 mode header. Prior to this PR there was no means of adding this header.

title: Add support for encoding GS1 formatted QR

[Feature Request] stitch file together (minus header) across multiple QR codes
body:
Cryptocurrency users dislike connecting their cold wallets to internet connected computer, however there is need to transfer files back and forth.
I have a project that can split a Monero signed_tx file into approximately 21 QR codes that play in a loop.
[https://github.com/nasaWelder/sandbox/tree/master/monero/coldqr](https://github.com/nasaWelder/sandbox/tree/master/monero/coldqr)


The format is:
srcfilebasename,srcfilecrc32,1/21:bunchofasciiencodedtedtxt12345
srcfilebasename,srcfilecrc32,2/21:bunchofasciiencodedtedtxt12345
...
...
srcfilebasename,srcfilecrc32,21/21:bunchofasciiencodedtedtxt12345

I'd want the bulk scanning to be able to know when it has scanned the total number of files derived from within the QR code, show status bar, and self exit.
Then prompt user to save (default name srcfilebasename), or email file.

title: ZXing creates wrong barcode (for text with leading asterisk?)
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Hi,

this is a follow-up of issue  #806. Now we are using version 3.3.1 and it solves all issue reported in #806.

In our project we create data matrix barcodes using ZXing (core-3.3.1.jar and javase-3.3.1.jar) in this way:
```java
        final DataMatrixWriter barcode = new DataMatrixWriter();
        final BitMatrix bitMatrix = barcode.encode(text, BarcodeFormat.DATA_MATRIX, 0, 0);
```
We create an image (java.awt.Image) using the bit matrix and scan this barcode image afterwards (form screen or paper). In 99% percent of all cases the text of the scanned barcode image is identical to the the encoded text.

But in some cases we get another text. Examples:

* original text -> converted to barcode
* `*CH/GN1/022/00` -> `*CH/GN1/022/{00`

I suppose the leading asterisk causes again the problem.
![inf_01_zxingcreatewrongbarocde](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23717092/33834779-7110b9b4-de84-11e7-85be-655a257b14bb.png)

title: FAQ: permissions explanations miss INTERNET
body:
Please include with your [FAQ](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/wiki/Frequently-Asked-Questions)

> Why does Barcode Scanner request permission to access ...

* … the Internet?

You've explained `ACCESS_WIFI_STATE` and `CHANGE_WIFI_STATE` (implicitly, though not differentiating which is which) but omitted `INTERNET`; tin-foils like me get suspicious about such omissions. Alternatively (and even better) if you could drop that permission? I can't see why a Barcode-Scanner would need it :wink:

title: Raised Digits lead to wrongly detected EAN-13
body:
Scanning EAN-13 codes formatted in a certain way leads to wrongly detected EANs. It happens when the leading (human readable) digit is raised to the level of the bars and the bars have a relatively low height.

I assume that due to the low height of the overall code, some bounding box detection decides, that the raised digit may be part of the actual code, since removing the leading (human readable) digit results in a correct detection.

The behaviour can be easily reproduced with the described EAN-13 code layout. I attached a minimalistic code sample as well as two images which lead to an erroneous detection. However, trying to detect such kind of codes with different Applications that claim to use zxing leads to similar results.

[zxing_test.zip](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/1535996/zxing_test.zip)

![4017100131004](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34313625/33673768-079c826c-daae-11e7-939a-a98fb62e66f4.png)

![4017100131004_1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34313625/33673769-07b7a92a-daae-11e7-8c26-07d192b475a8.png)

title: add Micro QR Code encoder
body:
This PR adds support for Micro QR Code encoding.

One can use `BarcodeFormat.MICRO_QR_CODE` for `MultiFormatWriter` or `QRCodeWriter`.

Micro QR Code is widely used at medical and bio technology domain,
such as sample labeling for small area, as well as Data Matrix.


Although in this PR I didn't implemented decoder, I would do it later.

title: Suggestion to backport an improved datamatrix detector
body:
I needed a c++ library for datamatrix detection+decoding and found [this new c++ port](https://github.com/nu-book/zxing-cpp) of the ZXing library. [Like](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22381421/zxing-library-cant-decode-datamatrix-barcode) [other](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12721077/issue-to-read-multiple-barcodes-using-zxing-library) [people](https://github.com/glassechidna/zxing-cpp/issues/33#issuecomment-338646683), too, I quickly found out that the datamatrix detector is quite limited in capabilities.

The single biggest issue turned out to be the dependence on the `WhiteRectDetector` to look for a white bounding box parallel to the image borders that contains the datamatrix code and nothing else. So with many real world situations where you have some text near the code and the code is not perfectly aligned with the image border, like [here](http://www.neuhausag.ch/assets/uploads/images/produkte/Etiketten/Produkte_Etiketten_Barcodeetiketten_2DCode.jpg), [here](https://www.deutsche-apotheker-zeitung.de/_Resources/Persistent/55c53726b5bbcc918ec7800229cf2e9d27794c21/k4_931_258080_258181-800x343-660x283-482x271.jpg) or [here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Tvxeo.jpg), you have no chance. It also may lead to [this](https://github.com/glassechidna/zxing-cpp/issues/42) peculiar problem.

This led me to implement the detector from scratch with the main focus on two things:
 1. try to detect the code with as little quite zone as possible (1 module) and
 1. do that in an image with as low a resolution as possible.

What I came up with can be found [here](https://github.com/nu-book/zxing-cpp/blob/2ceda95cba943b3b2ab30af3c90150c97e84d416/core/src/datamatrix/DMDetector.cpp#L442-L1072). It is currently capable of detecting all the samples from the blackbox tests and a lot more challenging ones, like the mentioned examples above.

This would require a couple hours worth of JAVA coding, so it is probably not going to happen. But maybe it would make sens to keep this issue open so someone who also needs a better datamatrix detector and is willing to spend that effort might find the info I assembled here.

title: DataMatrix encoder broken for certain short EDIFACT messages
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
I'm helping out at a new C++ port of this code base (https://github.com/nu-book/zxing-cpp). I stumbled on an issue with messages encoded with EDIFACT that need 2 code words padding. During debugging and research I found out that this issue has been discovered "upstream" over 5 years ago: https://sourceforge.net/p/barcode4j/bugs/38/.

Steps to reproduce: create a DataMatrix with the message `<ABCDEFG><ABCDEFGK>` -> the resulting image contains an invalid code.

I don't have a pull request but the fix is just one line, see [here](https://github.com/nu-book/zxing-cpp/pull/24/commits/06cbdadecf05c4360ba8e5ee502e17e7f4be8b30).

title: Code 39 cannot be recognized when wrapped with box
body:
The zxing library has trouble with recognizing barcodes (Code 39) when the barcodes are wrapped in a box.  

For example, the following barcode (code 39) can be recognized quickly. 
![code39_no_box](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3282634/32619678-c2b4f11c-c57b-11e7-9990-d606302e5649.png)

The following barcode (code 39) can not be recognized. However, as soon as the box's left border got hidden (by a piece of white paper). The barcode can be immediately recognized.
![code39_box](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3282634/32619672-bf58735e-c57b-11e7-9bac-b6ee98c33b08.png)

I tested with official BarcodeScanner, zxing.org and my customized app built on top of zxing. 
I also tested with Code 128 and there is no problem for recognizing it.

title: Finding false QR Code centers
body:
Problematic QR Code:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8955362/32093202-cb1d737c-bafb-11e7-899e-98686c6d4b55.png)

Finding (also changing the angle of the QR code to 45° scans successfully):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8955362/32093249-f5e1f402-bafb-11e7-84c1-daaf8513821a.png)

After further investigation it seems the vertical and horizontal pattern is accepted at the above incorrect center, for this particular QR Code.
Which lead me to come across these concerns:

It seems at [FinderPatternFinder.java:78](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/qrcode/detector/FinderPatternFinder.java#L78)
`pureBarcode = hints != null && hints.containsKey(DecodeHintType.PURE_BARCODE);`
the default for `pureBarcode` is false (I'd rather assume most QR Codes are pure monochrome?)
eg. `pureBarcode = hints == null || hints.containsKey(DecodeHintType.PURE_BARCODE);`

In any case at [FinderPatternFinder.java:496](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/qrcode/detector/FinderPatternFinder.java#L496) it seems that the diagonal check is ignored when it is not monochrome (`!pureBarcode || crossCheckDiagonal(...`). This seems strange can someone please explain the reasoning behind this, I don't understand it. According to me it should still do the check regardless if it is a `pureBarcode` or not.

I'll submit a pull request if required.

**meaning of Pure Barcode:**
```
  /**
   * Image is a pure monochrome image of a barcode. Doesn't matter what it maps to;
   * use {@link Boolean#TRUE}.
   */
  PURE_BARCODE(Void.class),
```
_DecodeHintType.java_

title: QR codes scan return error（扫描联系人二维码返回错误）
body:
I had a problem with Android development: when I was using zxing to scan complex contact QR codes, the scan results in occasional commodity and text.

According to my analysis, the reason of the problems is that the image frame inside the scanning of the local features with the bar code, so it is identified as the recognition algorithm of bar code, but the code is of no practical significance, therefore through the network query, and can query to the bar code corresponding to the product, so there are the phenomenon described in bug. Excuse me, is there a solution?

Chinese：
我在Android开发中遇到一个问题：我在使用zxing扫描比较复杂的联系人二维码的时候，扫描结果偶尔会出现商品、文本。

根据我的分析，该问题出现的原因是，扫描的图像帧里面，局部区域特征符合了条形码，因此被识别算法识别为条形码，但该条形码是没有实际意义的，因此通过联网查询时，并不能查询到该条形码对应的商品，所以出现了bug中所描述的现象。请问一下这是否有解决办法？

Contact Me：1435378192@qq.com

title: Copyright violation
body:
Hi @zxing

I found [this app](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.cha3.zxing.client.android) on the Google Play Store. This guy just took your source code, added some ads in it and put it on the Store, without warning this is free software...

As you are the owner of the source code, feel free to open a request to google [here](https://support.google.com/legal/contact/lr_dmca?product=googleplay) to remove the false app from the Store, if it's your wish ;)

Don't forget to tell Google that:

* The app is licensed under Apache v2.0 license and this guy is violating it;
* He is falsely claiming he made the app;
* Provide a link to this repo, a screenshot of your app and a screenshot of the fake app.

body:
The codes with preceding % are not linear arranged in the symbol table.
Changes are based upon https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code39#Full_ASCII_Code_39

title: asterisk isn't a valid character and should not be encoded as content with Code 39.
body:
the following sample content results in an unreadable barcode: *123456789
because the asterisk is the start-stop character (special meaning, not valid in content)
the really encoded value is **123456789*. The barcode reader stops after reading the second asterisk
and throw the content away.

When I scan the barcode and tap "Dial number", the dialer pops up with `8351[redacted]` instead of `1[redacted]`. title: ITF Writer should add checksum if odd length String should be encoded
body:
According to [this](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interleaved_2_of_5) ITF uses the (already implemented) UPC algorithm to add a checksum to odd length strings. please use the implemented algorithm to add the check sum instead of throwing an exception in case an odd length string should be encoded.

i would call the method directly and by hand, but there is no release on Maven with the fixes for #679 that introduced a method for generating the checksum (albeit in package security, so i can't even call it if there WAS a release)

scaning colour qr code
body: zxing包不支持扫描多种颜色混合的二维码，如果是多种颜色混合的二维码，可能会有部分色块丢失，导致无法识别。查看源码发现，在解码过程中，二维码图片会被解析成黑白图片做解析，彩色的部分有可能会在转黑白时丢失，导致解码失败。经过尝试微信、qq、百度都可以正常解析彩色二维码，还请大牛协助解决。感激不尽。

title: Problem with looping the http://zxing.appspot.com/scan function
body: Hi, I love ZXing and have used it for a few projects now. My most recent problem is a bit trickier. I want to make a web browser that links to http://zxing.appspot.com/scan to retrieve barcode data. It works perfectly, until I try to run the function twice, even with a few seconds gap in between. To prove my error, I have created 2 files; index.html and return.html and you can experience this here: http://karl-cooper.co.uk/zxingtest/v1/ The first one always works, the second one never does, you are greeted with 'you need to install free Barcode Scanner -app' even though I obviously have it as I used it seconds ago. File sources are as follows: **index.html (this is used to start the loop)** `Click here to start recursive scanning` **return.html (this is used to continue the loop)** `Thank you for the data from the barcode, now I will send the user back to read another! ` PLEASE NOTE THAT I TESTED THIS ON A SAMSUNG GALAXY S7 AND IT ISN'T WORKING.

title: BitMatrix.get() throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
sharing screen of android contacts with e164 numbers is showing the wrong number
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="bug")]
body:
Steps to reproduce:

- have a contact with a phone number in the e164 format
- share the contact with the barcode scanner

![1845297871461598955_2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10261186/28911439-cd6b6656-7830-11e7-88dd-ead3dab5c2e6.png)

As you can see, the barcode scanner is displaying the country prefix (+49 since it is a german phone number), but it somehow cut off the `+` character.

title: Cropping an image reads differently
body:
When reading a CODE-128 barcode from an image, ZX cannot read it properly (it will sometimes add random chars in between).

However, if I crop the image to remove whitespace from the edges, ZX can successfully read the barcode. 

Here is a video explaining the issue:  https://www.screencast.com/t/BnjtDyLB

[Images.zip](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/1140042/Images.zip)

title: CommandLineEncoder appears to ignore the height and width parameters when barcode_format is  DATA_MATRIX
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
`CommandLineEncoder` appears to ignore the height and width parameters when `barcode_format` is  `DATA_MATRIX`

The following command produces a 14px by 14px image instead of a 500px by 500px image: 

```
java -cp javase/target/javase-3.3.0-jar-with-dependencies.jar com.google.zxing.client.j2se.CommandLineEncoder --barcode_format DATA_MATRIX --height 500 --width 500 abcdefg
```

Here's a `Dockerfile` to reproduce this issue:

```
FROM ubuntu:16.04
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends default-jdk git maven
RUN git clone --depth 1 --branch zxing-3.3.0 https://github.com/zxing/zxing.git
RUN cd zxing && mvn install -DskipTests
RUN cd zxing/javase && mvn -DskipTests package assembly:single
RUN cd zxing && java -cp javase/target/javase-3.3.0-jar-with-dependencies.jar com.google.zxing.client.j2se.CommandLineEncoder --barcode_format DATA_MATRIX --height 500 --width 500 abcdefg
```

Is this a bug or am I using `CommandLineEncoder` wrong?

title: Barcode scanner does not scan when iOS is in portrait mode
QR Code NotFoundException on text containing "=="
body:
![screenshot_1460](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/210750/26608440/31939d4a-4561-11e7-96e1-67a08483c024.png)
Hello,

I am trying to read a chunk of Base64 encoded data with `QRCodeReader().decode(binaryBitmap, hintMap);`

 Everything works until the QRCode has `==` double equals characters (Base64 padding). 

Example: `ZG9kb2RvCg==`

If the offending characters are encountered I get `NotFoundException`.  I have tried various combinations of CHARACTER_SET in hints but so far no success.
```
hintMap.put(DecodeHintType.CHARACTER_SET, CharacterSetECI.UTF8);
hintMap.put(DecodeHintType.TRY_HARDER, true);
```

Screenshot of the QRCode is attached. Any solution or workaround is appreciated.

title: I only want to scan EAN_13 barcode with EAN-2 Addon / EAN-5 Addon.
I only want to scan EAN_13 barcode with EAN-2 Addon / EAN-5 Addon
ZXing creates wrong barcode (for text with leading asterisk?)
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Hi,

in our project we create data matrix barcodes using ZXing (core-3.3.0.jar and javase-3.3.0.jar) in this way:
```java
        final DataMatrixWriter barcode = new DataMatrixWriter();
        final BitMatrix bitMatrix = barcode.encode(text, BarcodeFormat.DATA_MATRIX, 0, 0);
```
We create an image (```java.awt.Image```) using the bit matrix and scan this barcode image afterwards (form screen or paper). In 99% percent of all cases the text of the scanned barcode image is identical to the the encoded text.

But in some cases we get another text. Examples:
* original text -> converted to barcode
* `*MEMANT-1F-MESTECH` -> `*MEMANQ90E5079ROO70` 
* `*MEMANT-1F-M-2estech` -> `*MEMANQ90E5089q{estech` 
* `*MEMANT-1F-M-2e-stech` -> `*MEMANQ90E5089q{e-stech` 
* `*MEMANT-1F-M6ABCDEF` -> `*MEMANQ90E5091` 

I suppose the leading asterisk causes the problems.

title: Only two finder patterns were found when decoding qrcode
body:
I am using `zxing` to decode a qrcode image. Both the [online decoder](https://zxing.org/w/decode.jspx) and directly using `zxing J2SE` API failed to decode the specific image. After debugging the `QrcodeDecoder`, I found it only found two finder patterns from the image.

![zxing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/843303/25226785/bc6e13ce-25f8-11e7-9c1e-d30d1e05bbaa.jpg)

However the image can be decoded properly by other qrcode services, such as [this one](http://www.onlinebarcodereader.com/).

title: QR codes sometimes take much time to recognize.
body:
I made Android QR codes reader application.
Most QR codes usually recognize immediately after focusing the QR codes. However some QR codes take much time to recognize even after focusing them. It takes from 10 to 30 seconds, but not always.
QR codes are made by my system, so I could not find any differences among them. The quality of print is also same. It occur about 1 per 100 QR codes. Most of all QR codes are recognize easily.
I am using Torque G01 Android 4.4 OS, made by Kyocera Android.

Unfortunately so I can’t send the QR codes, because they include customer name.
Could you tell me if there is similar case? Or is there any consideration about source code to avoid this case?
Thank you for your help.

title: Bar code identification error
body:
Hello, I am a Android developer from China, is using the 3.3.0 version of the library, a problem encountered in the development:
I recognize the CODE_128 format of the bar code, the content is 99770280035299, in the frame offset slightly to the left or right of about 20 degrees, will be identified as such as UPC_E, EAN_8 format, such as [UPC_E]01723047, [UPC_E]12668515, [EAN_8]18788082 content, test mobile phone Samsung GalaxyGrand2, xiaomi4S, OPPOA59M, HUAWEI enjoy 5S.
At present, I can only shield UPC_E and EAN_8 format, I would like to ask the above problems have a better solution? Thank you

title: Improve Datamatrix Scan Performance
body:
Thanks for maintaining zxing, it's probably the best open source library for barcodes out there.

Currently, I am trying to scan datamatrix codes, however, scan performance is not very good (see attachment), especially with larger (6x6) datamatrix codes. Scanning from my screen while the codes are enlarged is doable, but It's nearly impossible to scan the attached codes from printed pages.

I am aware that this project is in maintenance mode and this is more or less a feature request. However, if you could point me in the direction of some other library (or just the necessary optimizations) which offer/s better datamatrix scan performance, I would be happy integrate the code into zxing and file a pull request.

Attached file:
[Testfälle_bmp023.pdf](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/799996/Testfalle_bmp023.pdf)

Further information and background:
Germany has decided to standardize medication plans (see examples in attachment pdf). They chose to use datamatrix instead of qr codes (hm). The first smartphone apps in the app stores seem to be licensing proprietary scan technology.

So at the moment our options are:
- Everyone licenses proprietary scanners
- Change the standard from datamatrix to qr codes (better scanning performance)

If we don't find an open-source library which delivers satisfactory datamatrix scanning performance, we're in for a fun ride..

Any answer is greatly appreciated. Thanks!

title: Problem using  zxing 3.3.0 with ant's artifact:dependencies
body:
I changed a pom.xml entry to zxing to 3.3.0 
```

		<dependency>
			<groupId>com.google.zxing</groupId>
			<artifactId>core</artifactId>
			<version>3.3.0</version>
		</dependency>
		<dependency>
			<groupId>com.google.zxing</groupId>
			<artifactId>javase</artifactId>
			<version>3.3.0</version>
		</dependency>
		<dependency>
		  <groupId>com.google.zxing</groupId>
		  <artifactId>zxing-parent</artifactId>
		  <version>3.3.0</version>
		  <type>pom</type>
		</dependency>
```

and now I'm getting this:

```
    [artifact:dependencies] Unable to resolve artifact: Unable to get dependency information: Unable to read the metadata file for artifact 'com.github.jai-imageio:jai-imageio-core:jar': Invalid JDK version in profile 'java8-and-higher': Unbounded range: [1.8, for project com.github.jai-imageio:jai-imageio-core
    [artifact:dependencies]   com.github.jai-imageio:jai-imageio-core:jar:1.3.1

```

From what I can find this indicates that something is wrong with the pom file for zxing related to the required versions of java (which I'm using java 8)?

The code compiles fine using Maven and Eclipse, but this error occurs when attempting to run a separate ant process.

	<artifact:dependencies filesetId="dependency.fileset">
		<artifact:pom file="${basedir}/pom.xml"/>
	</artifact:dependencies>

The ant task works just fine if I use zxing 2.2 in the pom but then of course my code does not.
Is this a bug in zwing 3.3.0 or am I missing something?

title: Android vCard parse: type default / type order
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="bug")]
body:
Barcode scanner seems to be using different type defaults for `ADR` and `TEL` than suggested in the specification (at least for vCard 2.1). For me it defaults to 'private' but it should to 'work'. From looking at the code it seems that there is no default internally. This can also result in wrong order of types, e.g. this vCard data will swap the types of the second and third number.  

```
BEGIN:VCARD
N:;John;;;
TEL;WORK:10
TEL:2
TEL;CELL:30
END:VCARD  
```

IMHO a good solution for both issues would be to default to the type 'WORK' for phone numbers and addresses at parse time. This should be close enough to the specification. Maybe also for eMails.  

I guess this could be implemented by adding a `defaultType` Parameter to the function `matchVCardPrefixedField` in VCardResultParser.java?

title: Recommend QR version bug
body:
First sorry for my Chinglish.

I define a Class to creat qrcode here:  [QRUtil](https://gist.github.com/liu-ning/9debcae8b0bdb81fca7cfb215f63271f)


Example:  

String content = "https://itunes.apple.com/cn/app/id1180510476";

I set `MARGIN ` to 0, but, the result QRCode image's margin is not 0. The QRCodeWriter did not choose the right QR VERSION.

`recommendVersion` function return "qr version 5", but the "qr version 6" should be the right choose.

qrcode_version_5( auto choose version)
![qrcode_version_5](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4246362/21712688/117160ac-d431-11e6-8f18-bd00c2c7373b.jpg)

title: Add support for non-interleaved/standard two-of-five
body:
This is a copy-and-paste-and-change of the Interleaved 2-of-5 reader to support the non-interleaved or standard variant of the Bar-Code.
Two black-box tests also supplied, test suit passes.

title: OOB Exception in PDF417 file
body:
This exception happened while the camera/scanner was idle (the camera was focussing the table, a black surface). This might have been caused by interference.

Unfortunately, this is hard to reproduce, at least there is a stack trace:

```
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: length=929; index=-488
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.ec.ModulusGF.multiply(ModulusGF.java:105)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.ec.ModulusPoly.evaluateAt(ModulusPoly.java:99)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.ec.ErrorCorrection.decode(ErrorCorrection.java:53)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.PDF417ScanningDecoder.correctErrors(PDF417ScanningDecoder.java:556)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.PDF417ScanningDecoder.decodeCodewords(PDF417ScanningDecoder.java:529)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.PDF417ScanningDecoder.createDecoderResultFromAmbiguousValues(PDF417ScanningDecoder.java:308)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.PDF417ScanningDecoder.createDecoderResult(PDF417ScanningDecoder.java:277)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.PDF417ScanningDecoder.decode(PDF417ScanningDecoder.java:124)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.PDF417Reader.decode(PDF417Reader.java:87)
    at com.google.zxing.pdf417.PDF417Reader.decode(PDF417Reader.java:61)
    at com.google.zxing.MultiFormatReader.decodeInternal(MultiFormatReader.java:171)
    at com.google.zxing.MultiFormatReader.decode(MultiFormatReader.java:55)
```

title: scan not possible while exploiting error correction
body:
Hello, 

I'm currently working on an app, which exploits the error correction. I already read the qr specification and on page 45 I found the formula: 

"e + 2t ≤ d - p 
where: 
e = number of erasures 
t = number of errors 
d = number of error correction codewords 
p = number of misdecode protection codewords" 

where p=0 since i'm working with 3-H codes. After creating 11 errors in the data codewords of the first block, I cannot scan, which should be possible according to the formula. Is this a bug? 

QR Code with 11 errors; not scannable:
![qrcode_11errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3286570/20789912/7daa4b2c-b7b6-11e6-908b-3c6fa9bf78a9.png)

QR Code with 10 errors; scannable:
![qrcode_10errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3286570/20789913/7dd2f0f4-b7b6-11e6-9064-c451c6eb2b1f.png)

Original QR Code
![qrcode_correct](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3286570/20789914/7dd5cfea-b7b6-11e6-8910-8ed6f00b9674.png)

Best, 
Carsten

title: CODE_128 throws IllegalArgumentException when encoding control characters
body:
[CODE 128](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_128) encodes all characters in ASCII between Unicode code points 0 and 127, inclusive.
However, this fails for all characters u0000 to u0019, inclusive:

```java
MultiFormatWriter().encode('\u0000', BarcodeFormat.CODE_128, width, height, null)
```

If the phone is in the portrait mode, the reading screen remains in landscape mode and I'm unable to read the code (when [read more...](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.zxing.client.android&reviewId=Z3A6QU9xcFRPRks1QVVCTXRtX0pxeS1zVW1QQ0JxSFY3QUlzVDc4c2d2cUhDRVVHMV9JbDNnOTBLRXRiSnVpNWg2Qk43WlVHY0t4bHhTa20yX2tzRnZOTVE)

Works well and a good, reliable app, but however. Need to hold my phone very still to work. Also need to have barcode item on a surface. Can't hold both to scan. Only scans in landscape mode. title: openCameraWithPermission function not work
Problem with ZXing on iOS 10.1 (Xamarin)
body:
Hi,

We are having some troubles with ZXIng on IOs 10.1. 
On scanning we are getting this (we are using xamarin) while it crashes:

Got a SIGSEGV while executing native code. This usually indicates
a fatal error in the mono runtime or one of the native libraries 
used by your application.

Here is a fix (at the end of the thread - in code of zxing - ZXingscannerview.cs), but I don't understand why this could fix the problem. Do you have a better fix?

Thanks,
Cyber1000

title: zxing can not decode utf-8 encoded Chinese Characters  QR code
body:
Hi,
  I am using zxing Barcode Scanner , I found it can not decode a utf-8 encoded Chinese String.but I use some apps can decode the QR code correctly .such as wechat .Taobao.  if I encode the String with GBK to generate QR code，it works find 。 I traced the code in zxing/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/qrcode/decoder/DecodedBitStreamParser.java  .   I found the decoder goes to wrong mode.    mode = Mode.forBits(bits.readBits(4));  the result is Mode.KANJI .so it calls decodeKanjiSegment method next。the full messy code is “201610170063400000010285，麻譚冗浹逕伜哨譛肴��，兽药字（2012）050036112，蒙瑞普大地，0472-2209620”，and the right String is “201610170063400000010285，麻杏石甘口服液，兽药字（2012）050036112，蒙瑞普大地，0472-2209620”
> step 1 ： NUMERIC  mode  we got  “201610170063400000010285”
> step 2 ：BYTE  mode  we got  “，麻”
> step 3：KANJI mode  we got  “譚冗浹逕伜哨譛肴”  this step was wrong the String should be 杏石甘口....
> step 4： BYTE  mode  we got  “��，兽药字（2012）”  the messy code in this step i think is related with step 3.
> step 5：NUMERIC  mode  we got  “050036112”
> step 6：BYTE  mode  we got  “，蒙瑞普大地，0472-”
> step 7：NUMERIC  mode  we got  “2209620”

you can find the QR code picture： http://pan.baidu.com/s/1c1CsJNq

can you tell me why this happens？or actually  I can not encode the String with UTF-8 in the frist place？but why WeChat and taobao can decode it。

title: scan not saved to clipboard in bulk scanning mode

title: zxing.appspot.com/scan contains mixed content

When I looked at the browser's console, it says that there are blocked contents because they are served with http (instead of https). The contents are Jquery and the Droid Sans font. I'm using Mozilla Firefox 49.0.2. It seems that Firefox is, by default, blocking active contents served through http pulled from https page.

body:
I found it better to not use this mode becouse it sets focus on start and then never tweak it again later. 

It is returned in AutofocusManager as currentFocusMode and maks useAutoFocus == false.

For me it worked better if currentFocusMode is 'auto' than 'continous-video' becouse it start autofocusing by focus() and autoFocusAgainLater() by AutoFocusManager. 

"... The focus position is locked after autoFocus call ...."
source:
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/hardware/Camera.Parameters.html#FOCUS_MODE_CONTINUOUS_VIDEO

title: When 'No automatic rotation' is on, camera stops working

The screen is rotated to portrait but there is no preview and whole screen is converted to black. After you change rotation to any mode then there is no any effect or change in orientation. So what is the exact use of 'No automatic rotation' ? I think it is not working.

title: Various small encoding improvements
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
A couple related improvements from https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/zxing/iCODr5bZKHk
- UPC-E, EAN-13 and EAN-8 writers should add check digit if not present, like UPC-A does.
- They should all check the check digit if provided and reject the barcode if it fails
- The default margin for UPC/EAN barcodes should never result in a margin less than the mandated 9 modules
- Experiment with less tolerance of small quiet zones

title: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zxing
body:
(Please remove this text once you've read and understood it.)
## Contributing

The project is in maintenance mode, meaning, changes are driven by contributed patches.
There is otherwise no active development or roadmap for this project. It is "DIY".

Only proposed changes in the form of a pull request are likely to be acted on, but,
these will be acted on promptly.
###  Questions

Questions should be asked on the mailing list:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zxing
### Feature Requests

Feature requests are not accepted and will generally be closed.
Feature requests with a pull request may be accepted. When in doubt, discuss on the
mailing list first.
### Bug Reports

Bug reports must have enough detail to understand and reproduce the problem. Inadequate
bug reports will be closed with a request for more information.

Bug reports without an associated pull request are not likely to be addressed, but will be
left open for some time to see if anyone can contribute a solution. However, bug reports
with a pull request are likely to be merged promptly.

title: zxing-javase: DecoderConfig's possibleFormats param requires a custom converter
body:
JCommander can't infer custom types without a [diy-ed custom converter](http://jcommander.org/#Custom_types). Though List of Integer/String/Long are supported, List<BarcodeFormat> isn't.

title: Core: Aztec decoding fails for large symbols unless pixel-perfect
body:
Scanning any Aztec code larger than approximately 67x67 with a mobile phone running BarcodeScanner-4.7.5.apk is very difficult in my experience, becoming entirely infeasible at 91x91 (or more); when NeoReader on the same mobile phone (Galaxy S6) scans these with great ease, 

The problem lies in ZXing core. It is repeatable on test images of excellent visual quality. At size 91x91, ZXing (e.g. as of [here](https://zxing.org/w/decode.jspx)) fails to detect Aztec codes in images that are even so slightly imperfect. For example the following detailed but slightly blurred image of a 91x91 code
![blurred91](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17367222/74d267c6-598f-11e6-89ee-6ad673583228.png)

The above image was obtained by digitally stretching the pixel-perfect image below, which is detectable by ZXing when processing the file directly
![pass91](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17367350/eb7b0e6e-598f-11e6-954a-cecf5dcb0a01.png)

There's the same problem with this 0.1 degree rotation of the pixel-perfect image
![rotated](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17390313/486cd478-5a0c-11e6-9118-7bf002ac8e00.png)

I conclude improvement is much needed in com.google.zxing.aztec.detector (or what it uses), but have not any clue about what, or how to make progress. Any idea?

title: Core: DecoderResult's rawBytes comes without bit length indication, ambiguity arises
body:
The [DecoderResult class](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/common/DecoderResult.java#L28) has a getRawBytes() method returning a byte array with the raw code's content. Problem is, there's no way to know exactly how many bits are in there: up to 7 bits in the last byte can be unused (in which case they are zeroes, and indistinguishable from actual bits at zero). This can be a cause of ambiguity, to the point that codes with different contents can have the same RawBytes, defeating its use as an inspection tool. For examples, these two Aztec codes both have RawBytes
`f5 55 55 75 6b 5a d6 b5 ad 6b 5a d6 b5 ad 6b 5a d6 b5 ad 6b 5a d6 b0`
but the left one one contains
`88888TTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT`
while the right one contains
`88888TTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTO`
![t](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17342852/69115698-58fb-11e6-8e4d-846751baa59a.png)                       ![to](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17340857/46a7eada-58f2-11e6-8711-e7c5f4fed16b.png) Both are plain vanilla Aztec codes generated with [bwip-js](http://bwip-js.metafloor.com/demo/demo.html) using `format=full eclevel=31` and their respective content. At the end of the rawBytes, the `b0` byte actually contains the bits `1001` in the left code and `10010000` in the right code, and that changes the decoded content. The issue is one of design of the DecoderResult class. I see two ways to fix this: 1. Extend the DecoderResult class (in package com.google.zxing.common) with a getRawBytesBitSize() method returning an int telling how many bits there are in what getRawBytes() returns. This will leave any existing code working (including zxing's own test code), and requires no change in existing decoders when they never leave unused bits in RawBytes, or when that somewhat does not matter. 2. Fill any unused bits of the last byte in RawBytes with bits at one rather than zero in package com.google.zxing.aztec.decoder. That makes it possible to unambiguously decode RawBytes into content of the Aztec code for any standard-conforming Aztec code, because extra one bits can only produce content if the length of an earlier byte shift sequence was followed by less than 8 times that number of bits (something ISO/IEC 24778:2008 does not condone). Method 1 is certain to cause no compatibility issue, but makes the full interface of the DecoderResult class more complex, Method 2 might not be extensible to all symbologies (if any other turns out to be affected by the limitation of the design of the DecoderResult class), often modifies the last byte in RawBytes returned for a given Aztec code (which in turn will require simple changes to zxing's test code specific to the Aztec decoder), and could conceivably silently break some existing application code. On the other hand this method - is likely to fix existing application code decoding RawBytes according to ISO/IEC 24778:2008; - ensures that when rebuilding a code from its RawBytes alone, even when the image is different (which can still happen), the content is the same (with aforementioned exceptions involving non-conforming original; also, attempted rebuilding could still fail if the few extra bits cause the maximum capacity to become exceeded); - makes the existing [ZXing Decoder Online](https://zxing.org/w/decode.jspx) and similar tools more useful as a debugging aid if left without modification to show what the hypothetical new getRawBytesBitSize() gives; - causes the less code bloat. Any thoughts on what's the way to go?

The original code fails tests for core on the added test case; the source change fixes that.

title: Core: Aztec decoding incorrect for codes with U/S B/S
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
ZXing (as of July 25, 2016) decodes the following Aztec code as 3333h3i3j33333, when that should I believe be 3333h3i3jITIT per a literal reading of the ISO/IEC 24778:2008 standard, and is what I get with at least one popular decoder independent of ZXing (NeoReader). ![dlusbs.png](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17298916/4fe36296-580c-11e6-8345-6ba524b7d232.png) The binary sequence in that code, before applying the process of _14.5.2 Interpreting the bit stream_ in the standard, is the bit sequence 11110010101010101010111111111100101011010000011001101101001001100110110101001010101010101010101 which parses to ``` per ZXing per the standard and Neoreader 11110 (D/L) 11110 (D/L) 0101 3 0101 3 0101 3 0101 3 0101 3 0101 3 0101 3 0101 3 1111 (U/S) 1111 (U/S) 11111 (B/S) 11111 (B/S) 00101 [5] 00101 [5] 01101000 h 01101000 h 00110011 3 00110011 3 01101001 i 01101001 i 00110011 3 00110011 3 01101010 j 01101010 j 0101 3 01010 I 0101 3 10101 T 0101 3 01010 I 0101 3 10101 T 0101 3 ``` The discrepancy boils down to diverging interpretation of : > Byte Shift (B/S) is a special case, shifting into a run length-controlled string of literal 8-bit bytes. Following a B/S is a 5-bit binary value: if non-zero, it encodes the number of bytes (1 to 31) that follow, but if zero then the next 11 bits encode the number of bytes less 31. Byte Shift can thus encode either isolated extended ASCII or control characters or long strings of byte data, possibly filling the whole symbol. At the end of the byte string, **encoding returns to the _mode_ from which B/S was invoked**. The closest thing to a definition of _mode_ would be > The Upper and Lower code sets contain upper and lowercase alphabetic characters respectively; Mixed contains a mixture of ASCII control and punctuation characters; Punctuation contains common punctuation characters and combinations; and Digit contains the numerals plus some punctuation (..)
Message encoding starts in the Upper code set, and can be latched (semi-permanently, via U/L, L/L, M/L, P/L, or D/L) or shifted (for one character only, via U/S or P/S) into the other _modes_ as needed. In a literal interpretation, _mode_ means one of Upper, Lower, Mixed, Punctuation, and Digit; we are in Upper mode after U/S (even though that's only until the next character); thus "the _mode_ from which B/S was invoked" is Upper; thus we return to the Upper mode at the end of the Byte Shift sequence; and further, since there has been at least one character ( h ) in the Byte Shift sequence, the temporary Upper Shift has ceased to be in effect when the decoder _returns to the mode from which B/S was invoked_. The interpretation made by ZXing could to be that _the next character_ after U/S is B/S, and that ends the Upper sequence and brings back to Digit, and that's the mode in which B/S is invoked; however that is paradoxical since B/S does not appear in the codes of Digit mode; and requires to treat B/S as a character, while the _character set_ is defined as "all 8-bit values" plus "two non-data characters" (FNC1 and ECI), which does not include B/S. The only thing weakly in support of ZXing's interpretation is that annex H, table LatLen, counts 14 bits to go from Digit to Binary _and back_ including 5-bit length (when that would require 19 bits per the above literal interpretation). However annex H similarly miscounts how many bits it takes to go from Punctuation to Binary and back (as 15 bits rather than the unambiguous 20 bits); is a general mess; and is informative only, thus can not override normative parts of the standard. The problem is fixed (with no negative side effect, I hope) by inserting ``` latchTable = shiftTable; // after U/S B/S, return to Upper mode ``` between the two lines 133/134 of [core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/aztec/decoder/Decoder.java](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/aztec/decoder/Decoder.java#L133) currently reading ``` // Table changes if (str.charAt(6) == 'L') { ``` Of course a test case should be added in [core/src/test/resources/blackbox/aztec-1](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/tree/master/core/src/test/resources/blackbox/aztec-1), with dlusbs.png and the expected dlusbs.txt, as enclosed in this zip: [dlusbs.zip](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/394203/dlusbs.zip) The problem was detected by encoding test input 3333h3i3j33333 with a tentative direct implementation of the encoding algorithm in annex H, written on the assumption that it is optimal (it's stated goal) at least in the case of letters and digits. Decoding worked fine with ZXing, not with NeoReader. The root cause of the issue seems to be the messy annex H and ZXing's implementation of the decoder.

title: Remove build matrix in Coverity branch
plain pbm image format not working if whitespace in raster is omitted
body:
[foobar.zip](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/380393/foobar.zip)
Hello,

I don't know whether the following issue is due to your website image reader or due to your zxing library.
There is no impressum and no contact on your [website](https://zxing.org/w/decode.jspx) so I put the issue here.

When uploading a **plain PBM** image and there's no whitespace in the pbm's raster section, the website will prompt:

> **No Barcode Found**
> No barcode was found in this image. Either it did not contain a barcode, or did not contain one in a supported format, or the software was simply unable to find it. Go "Back" in your browser and try another image.

The [plain PBM specification](http://netpbm.sourceforge.net/doc/pbm.html) states:
- Each pixel in the raster is represented by a byte containing ASCII '1' or '0', representing black and white respectively.
- White space in the raster section is ignored.

In example gimp omits the spaces between the entries when an image is exported as pbm(ascii).
In the zip archive only file foobar2.pbm (with spaces inbetween) works and produces "foobar".

[foobar.zip](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/380395/foobar.zip)

title: DataMatrix C40 mode is exited unexpectedly
body:
We tried to encode the following sample data string: 

`JGB<Space>012000001200000042LL139TY2J09TY2J0<Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space>` (where `<space>` represents an actual single space character)

to a DataMatrix barcode with the following hints:

```
DATA_MATRIX_DEFAULT_ENCODATION: Encodation.C40
MIN_SIZE: [24x24]
MAX_SIZE: [24x24]
```

Resulting barcode: ![blob](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7415007/16592568/06f6ac28-42ea-11e6-85e7-23c35e433813.png)

It reads no problem, but our partner's system does not accept it, claiming that in the raw barcode data, right after `JCB`, there is a service character code 254 (`FE`) that ends the C40 encoding mode, and C40 mode is only reentered after `LL13`, whereas their system has a strict requirement for the C40 mode to be used throughout the entire barcode. The 24x24 size is also a strict requirement of theirs.

Indeed, raw barcode data, as reported by the ZXing online decoder, seems to match what they are saying:

```
e6 92 f0 fe 21 83 96 82   82 8e 82 82 82 ac 4d 4d
8f e6 56 8f 29 1d 13 3c   13 3c 13 3c 13 3c fe 21
81 88 1f b5 
```

`e6` at offset 0 starts C40, then there is `fe` at offset 3, then there is another `e6` at offset 17.

We believe this is not expected behaviour, or is it?

## Contributing

The project is in maintenance mode, meaning, changes are driven by contributed patches.
There is otherwise no active development or roadmap for this project. It is "DIY".

Only proposed changes in the form of a pull request are likely to be acted on, but,
these will be acted on promptly.
###  Questions

Questions should be asked on the mailing list:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zxing
### Feature Requests

Feature requests are not accepted and will generally be closed.
Feature requests with a pull request may be accepted. When in doubt, discuss on the
mailing list first.
### Bug Reports

Bug reports must have enough detail to understand and reproduce the problem. Inadequate
bug reports will be closed with a request for more information.

Bug reports without an associated pull request are not likely to be addressed, but will be
left open for some time to see if anyone can contribute a solution. However, bug reports
with a pull request are likely to be merged promptly.

title: Using Swagger with Zxing.org to make a barcode reading API
Improve efficiency of DataMatrix detector
body:
This pull request improves efficiency of DataMatrix detector in TRY_HARDER mode. Using existing image sets the DataMatrixBlackBox2TestCase decodes 6 more images in 0 degrees rotation, 1 more in 180 degrees rotation and 1 more in 270 degrees rotation.

The main motivation for the proposed changes was the poor decode results of DataMatrix reader having as input scanned images that contain DataMatrix barcodes. We had large sets of scanned images that have little distortion caused by the scanner or pencil lines by humans on the barcode. In this version we can read images like the following:

![cropimage1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3668016/16297307/cc3086dc-391f-11e6-8c81-590fb0223357.jpg)

![githubimage2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3668016/16297348/0894327c-3920-11e6-9e2b-e135b83cba78.jpg)

The main enhancements in detector algorithm are the following:
1.We don’t need to correct TopRight edge point, the edges are computed correctly from the beginning thus the initial computation of dimension does not need correction.
2.In order to compute transitions we sample more segments, moving edge points in proper direction. The final result is the most popular transition among samples.
3.To compute edge points in a rectangle we enhance the existing algorithm that uses getBlackPointOnSegment() with two more segments. The one moves on horizontal axis at double speed, and the other moves on vertical axis at double speed. Finally, we combine the results to compute the edge point.
4.We introduce tolerance in WhiteRectangleDetector. The result is that the algorithm is more efficient in low quality images with distortion. 
5.We enhance the calculation of transitions of a segment with a validation algorithm that compares each transition length to the length of the most popular transition. If a length is too small (probably sign of distortion of human interpolation) we investigate the problematic area and if find proofs of distortion we correct the calculation of transition.
Finally, there are no changes in algorithm in normal mode (that does not uses TRY_HARDER hint).

title: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException on files with only 1 pixel
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
When running on a file like https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pix.gif which has only 1 pixel, zxing throws an error:

```
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 1
    at com.google.zxing.common.GlobalHistogramBinarizer.getBlackRow(GlobalHistogramBinarizer.java:71)
    at com.google.zxing.BinaryBitmap.getBlackRow(BinaryBitmap.java:66)
    at com.google.zxing.oned.OneDReader.doDecode(OneDReader.java:132)
    at com.google.zxing.oned.OneDReader.decode(OneDReader.java:54)
    at com.google.zxing.MultiFormatReader.decodeInternal(MultiFormatReader.java:171)
    at com.google.zxing.MultiFormatReader.decode(MultiFormatReader.java:69)
    at com.google.zxing.multi.GenericMultipleBarcodeReader.doDecodeMultiple(GenericMultipleBarcodeReader.java:84)
    at com.google.zxing.multi.GenericMultipleBarcodeReader.decodeMultiple(GenericMultipleBarcodeReader.java:65)
    at com.google.zxing.client.j2se.DecodeWorker.decode(DecodeWorker.java:140)
    at com.google.zxing.client.j2se.DecodeWorker.call(DecodeWorker.java:75)
    at com.google.zxing.client.j2se.CommandLineRunner.main(CommandLineRunner.java:84)
```

Obviously barcodes will never exist in files that have 1 pixel, but zxing should not crash for it. (I'm running it on a lot of files, and this happened to be one of them)

The issue is that `localLuminance` in [GlobalHistogramBinarizer](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/b189fd1d5629770b1ecbdf3e2f55a37776538957/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/common/GlobalHistogramBinarizer.java#L71) directly accesses the 2nd element (which does not exist).

title: Code 128 and FNC1 error in autoswitching mode
body:
### Bug Reports

i try to encode ucc ean128 whit **not** force_codset_b ( space requirements)
if i encode string      Chr(241) & "100958" & Chr(241) & "17160526"   work
if i encode string      Chr(241) & "10958" & Chr(241) & "17160526"   doesn't work 

class return **System.FormatException**

i guess error returned from 
https://zxingnet.svn.codeplex.com/svn/trunk/Source/lib/oned/Code128Writer.cs
in instruction 
`patternIndex = Int32.Parse(contents.Substring(position, 2));` 

I guess the problem is related to the attempt to change the SUBSET automatically.
When the FNC1 is even , it is interpreted as a number and then goes into error.

title: Aztec decoder returns raw bytes
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
The Aztec decoder now packs the code bits into bytes and returns them as "raw bytes", even though the error correction codes and stuffing have been already removed.  Also added a couple of test cases for the byte-packing function.  This fixes issue #381.

title: Support for erasure correction
body: When dealing with Ethernet/IP network we deal with erasures instead of errors. We know which packets are missing so RS error correcting capability is increased by giving its position. Therefore, 1 parity symbol can recover from one erasure instead of 2 symbols for one error. I have an idea you must know all these details. Just wondering why there isn't any thing in the docs regarding passing error position to rs decoder so that its error correcting capability can be increased. Ior is there a way to tackle with erasures instead of errors in zxing?

title: cleaned up the new aztec decoder by @iSDP referenced in issue #381
body:
A while back @iSDP complained that the Aztec decoder does not return raw bytes like eg. the QR decoder. He made a PR [#389](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/pull/389), but it was rejected due to formatting issues.

I'd really like for this to work. Many Aztec barcodes don't store string data but compressed zlib streams, which get corrupted when turned into strings. The raw bytes would help.

I have not written any of the lines in this PR, only reformatted @iSDP's work to match the repo's conventions. I hope this is ok.

title: Fix spelling mistake in error message
body: Found a couple of spelling mistakes in a hard coded error message. This PR fixes this mistake.

title: Scan from web page removes query string keys
body:
For a web app I'm working on I am experimenting with adding support for scanning bar codes with the [scan from web](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/wiki/Scanning-From-Web-Pages) option using the zxing URI scheme. Depending on where in the web app the user decides to create a new item, a link like https://example.com/items/new?stuff_id=123 is generated so that certain fields can be prepopulated with 'stuff' data.

In order to not lose the prepopulated data, I included the query string in the return URL like this `zxing://scan/?ret=https://example.com/items/new?barcode=%7BCODE%7D&stuff_id=123` but after scanning I'm redirected to `https://example.com/items/new?barcode=9988776655` - the prepopulated 'stuff' fields are now empty.

Changing the order of the key/value pairs doesn't work either: `zxing://scan/?ret=https://example.com/items/new?stuff_id=123&barcode=%7BCODE%7D` bring me to `https://example.com/items/new?stuff_id=123` after scanning, so the barcode field is not populated.

I am using Barcode Scanner version 4.7.5 on an Xperia Z3 Compact running Android 5.1.1.

title: Use StringWriter to prevent race condition in println
body:
@srowen This pull request resolves a race condition seen in printing output in the command line runner. I'm not entirely sure why this occurs, but presumably the multithreaded execution of the command line runner can cause the `println` calls to be executed out of order. This is apparently something that [can happen with println in multithreaded execution](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19460987/why-is-system-out-prinln-out-of-order).

I found this occurs in two cases in my OS X environment. The first was when one of the input files is a symlink to another of input files. The second was when the files had very recently been written to disk by another program. I'm guessing in both cases, the data is already in memory, making the race condition more likely. The goofy output looks like this:

```
file:///Users/lucaswiman/opensource/zxing/javase/text1.png (format: QR_CODE, type: TEXT):
Raw result:
text1
Parsed result:
text1
Found 3 result points.
  Point 0: (44.0,156.0)
file:///Users/lucaswiman/opensource/zxing/javase/text1-symlink.png (format: QR_CODE, type: TEXT):
Raw result:
text1
Parsed result:
text1
  Point 1: (44.0,44.0)
Found 3 result points.
  Point 2: (156.0,44.0)
  Point 0: (44.0,156.0)
  Point 1: (44.0,44.0)
  Point 2: (156.0,44.0)

Decoded 2 files out of 2 successfully (100%)
```

Note that the points from the first file were printed while printing the points from the second file.

In order to avoid the race condition, I wrote the output using a `StringWriter` for each file, printing the output for each file when it's ready. My understanding is that `System.out.println` synchronizes the output buffer, so this should be a safe operation. 
## Testing

I tested this out with the following two runs below. The example files were this QR code, and a symlink to it:
![text1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123110/13041668/2e645404-d36e-11e5-9ac8-1e78fdd686a6.png)
### This branch

```
(for i in `seq 1 10`;
do
    java -Dapple.awt.UIElement=true -jar target/javase-3.2.2-SNAPSHOT-jar-with-dependencies.jar text1.png text1-symlink.png --multi
done) > /tmp/patched.output
```
### Compiled from 1fbefcac3146bf61efadb2d5da428b0f559d630c

```
(for i in `seq 1 10`;
do
    java -Dapple.awt.UIElement=true -jar target/javase-3.2.2-SNAPSHOT-jar-with-dependencies.jar text1.png text1-symlink.png --multi
done) > /tmp/1fbefcac3146bf61efadb2d5da428b0f559d630c.output
```

The output from those runs can be seen in [this gist.](https://gist.github.com/lucaswiman/e88775bc8b29c439258a)

title: PDF417 Decoder converting output to Unicode
body:
( I should note I am writing a PDF417 encoder -- using ZXing as part of my unit tests to verify my encoder )

I have encoded the following hex-string using mode 924 byte compaction `e7650b61cd02` -- which corresponds to the bytes `231 101 11 97 205`, or the codewords `924 387 700 208 213 302` after byte compaction. 

Zxing decodes ( through my script: https://gist.github.com/anall/ac92df67abc95419545d ) to the hex-encoded string `c3a7650b61c38d02`

This seems to coorespond to the following utf8-encoded "words": `c3a7 65 0b 61 c38d 02`

`c3a7` is `e7`, and `c38d` is `cd`

I should note I have tried a barcode created both with my encoder, and `zint` and get identical results.

A modification (which you can see hints of commented out in my script) I made to allow the decoded codewords to be exposed to my test script shows that both encoders contain the same codewords, ignoring padding and error correction.

the zint-created barcode has been attached.

![out](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12371/12876880/86fd12e0-cdce-11e5-8c5d-85b1a6a852b6.png)

Thank you.
