title: False positive EAN_8 barcode extracted in addition to correct UPC-A and QR-CODE barcodes
body:
I noticed the following when doing some testing of the zxing library. The image below contains a UPC-A barcode and a QR code, but when the `CommandLineRunner` is run with `--multi --try_harder`, it finds a spurious EAN 8 barcode. I'm guessing this is because part of the barcode is creased and UPC-A and EAN-8 use the same encoding. It presumably picks up the creased UPC-A barcode "part way through", finding something like an EAN-8 encoding.

Please free to close this issue as "won't fix". The issue isn't likely to cause many problems in practice, and `--try_harder` is a mode which I presume is prone to false positives. My hope was that you might be interested in a tricky false positive example to add to your collection of test cases if a fix is possible.

Thanks for all your work on this excellent library!
## How to reproduce

Note that only the QR code is found without `--try_harder`.

```
cd /tmp
git clone https://github.com/zxing/zxing.git
cd zxing
git checkout 1eaa66dbfac104c145aaf12f80383dd8e5a26bce
mvn package -DskipTests
cd javase
mvn -DskipTests package assembly:single
curl https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123110/12871393/de032b9e-cd2c-11e5-890a-bafca3285256.jpg > battery-package.jpg
java -jar target/javase-3.2.2-SNAPSHOT-jar-with-dependencies.jar battery-package.jpg --multi --try_harder
```
## Output

```
/tmp/zxing/javase $ java -jar target/javase-3.2.2-SNAPSHOT-jar-with-dependencies.jar battery-package.jpg --multi --try_harder
file:///private/tmp/zxing/javase/battery-package.jpg (format: QR_CODE, type: URI):
Raw result:
http://2d-scan.us/53655710
Parsed result:
http://2d-scan.us/53655710
Found 4 result points.
  Point 0: (1022.0,314.0)
  Point 1: (850.0,316.5)
  Point 2: (848.0,146.0)
  Point 3: (991.5,172.0)
file:///private/tmp/zxing/javase/battery-package.jpg (format: UPC_A, type: PRODUCT):
Raw result:
039800099099
Parsed result:
039800099099
Found 2 result points.
  Point 0: (1326.0,546.0)
  Point 1: (1326.0,99.5)
file:///private/tmp/zxing/javase/battery-package.jpg (format: EAN_8, type: PRODUCT):
Raw result:
77772114
Parsed result:
77772114
Found 2 result points.
  Point 0: (1163.0,1022.5)
  Point 1: (1163.0,743.5)
```
## Expected output

Same as above, but without the EAN_8 barcode.
## System information

OS X El Capitan 10.11.2.

```
$ java -version
java version "1.7.0_65"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0_65-b17)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 24.65-b04, mixed mode)
```
## Image

![batteries](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123110/12871393/de032b9e-cd2c-11e5-890a-bafca3285256.jpg)

title: Camera preview is black on second time.
Fixed coding bug in QRcode encoding mask penalty rule #3 calculation
body:
A bug exists in the way zxing calculates the mask to apply during QR code generation.

Eight masks have to be tested and the one with the lowest penalty is chosen to be applied to the QR code being created. Each mask is scored on four criteria (rules), and rule 3 gives a penalty based on a particular sequence of black and white squares being present in the code. 

zxing uses two helper functions `isWhiteHorizontal` and `isWhiteVertical`  to test if a given range of cells are all white (=0). 

However, a bug in the functions makes them return `true` even if the range of cells is out of range. This results often in higher rule 3 penalty values and can end up with a QR code choosing a suboptimal masking pattern.

title: Amazon app store
body:
Hello

I know its known that you all do not release to the amazon app store. However, I would like to request that you all to please release it to the amazon app store. 

Bluntly, my work has to work on all the variants, including amazon. As this seems to have some relation to google, I understand why there is semi aggressive talk of "third part app stores" and the like. Google vs amazon.. but the reality is we developers need this tool on both amazon and play. We don't get to just make it for one of the android platforms. If the tool doesn't work on all platforms then its a pretty poor tool. No major venture could hope to use this library. The fix would be a simple official release from you all to the app store, and 2 lines of code to direct it to the correct store.

Wouldn't be a major issue, if the library is easily turned into a jar and thus would be free of "what store" the user has access to. I've been poking at this with that in mind. Easy is not how I would describe it. I have seen several contributors saying that its desired I don't do exactly that. 

Anyways thats just my 2 cents. I'll obviously have a solution before theres a reply, let alone a real fix.

I have this http://forum.xda-developers.com/xperia-j-e/development/rom-cyanogenmod-10-dual-sim-t2518451 version of cyanogenmod installed. I am using the up-to-date version of Barcode Scanner from f-droid which is probably 4.7.5.
I generated a QR code using wolframalpha (http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=qr+code+for+%27%29%3B+DROP+TABLE+user%3B+--) with the text '); DROP TABLE user; --

I think the I set the error correction level to Q but I'm not sure. 

When I scanned the QR code everything was displayed as usual and nothing strange happened. When I tried to open a different app using the camera a message came up, that the camera could not be opened.

Then I tried to close the Barcode scanner but the view of the running apps kept disappearing. Then cm crashed and after reboot none of the SIMs were recognized. Some things still worked. Others didn't. Even after flashing cm again I can't charge my phone.

I'm not sure if this is caused by an SQL injection. ATM I'm not able or willing to try to reproduce.

title: False error alert when generating QRCode on Android device without GooglePlayServices.
body: Pretty much all in the title, but.. When generating a QRCode on an Android device without GooglePlayServices an error alert pops up for a split second and then goes away. The error alert says "This app won't run without Google Play services, Which are missing from your phone." Though the app runs fine and the QRCode is successfully generated. I understand why this may happen when attempting to scan a QRCode. Because, to my understanding (as I've only implemented generation, not scanning), it relies on Intents and the Google Play Store to open up a scanner app. But I don't see why this false alert pops up when generating a QRCode, because generation doesn't rely on any Google Play services, but maybe I'm overlooking something. This isn't a huge bug, as most of the Android users have Google Play services on their device, and the QRCode appears to be successfully generated. Also, the alert is only on the screen for a split second. But it would be good if we could stop the false error alert from popping up all together. Here's the error alert: Here's the Log output: `11-19 16:27:41.144 1189-1189/com.myApp.qrGeneration W/GooglePlayServicesUtil: Google Play Store is missing.` `11-19 16:27:41.148 1189-1189/com.myApp.qrGeneration I/qrGenerationActivity: [ main ] No valid Google Play Services APK found.`

title: Can't decode low contrast image
body:
I was write a problem about half years ago, and the problem still stands.(#315)

We are solved that problem using the Zbar and the Zxing library in one application. If the Zxing can't decode the QR code, our application use the Zbar library.

Now, in some devices fail the QR code determination both with the Zbar and the Zxing library, but the QRDroid successfully decoded the QR Data(with the Zapper engine).
Here is the picture:

![wrong qr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3351437/11252457/9bbdbd06-8e36-11e5-92b2-a66f1813319d.png)

I have got the latest Barcode Scanner application (https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.zxing.client.android&hl=hu).
From the previous issue, i have got two QR code with the same data structure, the first  one is lower contrast and not too good image quality, and the second one with good contrast and very high image qulaity.

![wrong qr2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3351437/11252471/a62fbef6-8e36-11e5-9082-257e3671a9be.png)

The QRDroid application read all of the QR codes(with the Zapper engine), but the Zxing(Barcode Scanner application) only read the QR 2(marked in the image).

Can you suggest me some solution? What can I do to fix this issue?

Thanks!

label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
The library is not able to scan some code39 barcodes with check digit.
I did the test with different barcodes.
- when the barcode ends with - or . checkdigit, it works
- when the barcode ends with $, %, + checkdigit, it doesn't work.

I think the problem is related to the calculation of the check digit (total variable) where we use the ALPHABET_STRING tab which contains the \* (star) character whereas the specification doesn't include this star character as part of the possible check digit (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_39)

title: Create a specific DataMatrixWriter to generate 2D-Doc
body:
2D-Doc is a specific usage of Datamatrix defined in France, see [1] for more information.

There is no issue to read 2D-Doc with zxing.

The only issue is about generation because 2D-Doc only uses ASCII encoding and does not optimize the encoding.

This patch:
- modify HighLevelEncoder to allow bypass of encodation optimization
- provide a new specific writer: DDDocWriter
- provide a 2D-Doc encoder
- provide some local changes to glue all the stuff

This is my first attempt with zxing, so I am waiting for your feedbacks to improve this proposal.

KR,
Guillaume

[1] https://ants.gouv.fr/content/download/516/5665/version/4/file/ANTS_2D-Doc_CABSpec_v2.0.1_erratum.pdf
in french, sorry

title: Add possibility to choose the error correction level for the encoding
How to recognize a leading Databar FNC1-character?
body:
Helllo,

The specification says that a leading FNC1-character is used to identify GS1 barcodes, and should be decoded as "]d2" (GS1 DataMatrix), "]C1" (GS1-128), "]e0" (GS1 DataBar Omnidirectional) or "]Q3" (GS1 QR Code). Any other occurrences of FNC1-characters should be decoded as ASCII GS-characters (byte value 29).  I managed to get FNC1-characters for DataMatrix, QR Code and GS1-128, but cannot do the same for DataBar because I don't have idea where to look at. 
Please, help me to understand how I can manage to get this leading FNC1-character "]e0"  for DataBar. Thanks.

Regards,
Ayaz

title: datamatrix raise checksum error even when no errors are found
body:
Hello,
I am facing a problem when zxing decode for datamatrix gives exception ChecksumException based on a failure of method ReedSolomonDecoder.findErrorLocations() that fails with exception ReedSolomonException.
The problem is that findErrorLocations() does not find any error since its error counter (the "e" variable) is kept at zero because errorLocator.evaluateAt(i) is never zero. This is of course strange since numErrors is not zero, and I don't know what is the meaning of this case.

I would like to know if the ReedSolomonException should _not_ be thrown when e==0.

Thanks,
Giuseppe

title: Ignore additional PDF417 barcode rows, https://github.com/zxing/zxing/issues/449
body:
Some barcode generators (e.g. Okapi) seem to generate additional barcode
rows at the end of the barcode, which can be decoded as valid barcode
rows, but actually contain garbage. The barcode metadata states that
these additional rows are not part of the barcode. So we ignore those
addional rows when parsing the barcode. This could potentially also
happen (though quite unlikely) if data after the barcode looks like a
barcode row.

title: Missing checks against null
body:
Hello,
Our security team has identified potential security concerns where null checks are not being performed:

/common/reedsolomon/ZXGenericGF.m:(Line 41)
common/reedsolomon/ZXGenericGF.m:(Line 40)
common/ZXHybridBinarizer.m:(Line 59)
common/ZXHybridBinarizer.m:(Line 150)
common/ZXHybridBinarizer.m:(Line 152)
pdf417/decoder/ec/ZXModulusGF.m:(Line 46)
pdf417/decoder/ec/ZXModulusGF.m:(Line 47)
core/ZXPlanarYUVLuminanceSource.m:(Line 114)

Impact:
This may lead to a memory crash enabling attackers to gain access
Recommendation:

If a function can return an error code or any other evidence of its success or failure, always check for the error condition, even if there is no obvious way for it to occur. In addition to preventing security errors, many initially mysterious bugs have eventually led back to a failed system call with an ignored return value.

title: Null Dereference Potential
body:
Hello,
Our security team has identified potential security issues:

ZXAztecReader.m:(Line 71)
ZXAztecReader.m:(Line 65)

Impact:
Most null pointer issues result in general software reliability problems, but if an attacker can intentionally trigger a null pointer dereference, the attacker might be able to use the resulting exception to bypass security logic or to cause the application to reveal debugging information that will be valuable in planning subsequent attacks.

Recommendation:
Implement careful checks before dereferencing objects that might be null. When possible, abstract null checks into wrappers around code that manipulates resources to ensure that they are applied in all cases and to minimize the places where mistakes can occur.

For example before doing

```
new MultiFormatWriter().encode(qrCodeData, BarcodeFormat.QR_CODE, codeWidth, codeHeight, map);
```

I would like to check

```
new MultiFormatWriter().encodable(qrCodeData, BarcodeFormat.QR_CODE);
```

which could either return true/false or throw Exceptions like the encode method.
In Ean13Writer are the validity checks provided at the start of encode(contents) method, so it should not be hard to extract them into separate public method and reuse, if the pattern is similar in all writers (did not check).
I am doing the generation asynchronous to the creation of db entry, but I need to know if the data are valid before the encoding proces.

title: OkapiBarcode plug
body:
Hi,

Sorry this isn't really an issue so much as something I wanted to let you know about, and I'm afraid I wasn't sure where/how else to do so...

I'm the main developer behind the Zint library which you link to in your README.md file. Firstly, can I let you know that I'm no longer developing or supporting Zint, so I think that link should be removed. But also that I am developing a Java-based replacement called OkapiBarcode which is right here on GitHub which includes most of the functionality from Zint including numerous bugfixes, and which, IMHO, has already surpassed Barcode4J in usefulness! It's still a moving target at the moment, but I thought it might be useful to ZXing users.

Thanks,

Robin.

title: The function ensureCapacity:() in ZXBitArray.m resizes a block of allocated memory on line 77.
body:
Details:"The function ensureCapacity:() in ZXBitArray.m resizes a block of allocated memory on line 77.

Pods/ZXingObjC/ZXingObjC/common/ZXBitArray.m:(Line 77)"

Impact:Do not use realloc() to resize buffers that store sensitive information.  The function might leave a copy of the sensitive information stranded in memory where it cannot be overwritten.

Fix:If sensitive information is stored in memory and there is a risk of an attacker having access to a memory dump, replace realloc() with explicit calls to malloc(), memcpy(), and free(). This approach gives you the opportunity to safely scrub the contents of the original buffer before it is freed.

title: Android project displaying QR-code can not find zxing classes in the jar files
Decode HTML entities in titles
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
This allows page titles with HTML entities like `&` to display properly. Before, no decoding would be performed and `&` would be shown where an ampersand should be. Additionally, decoding entities prevents the following string length check from overcounting.

To replicate this bug scan an image with a URL pointing to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/android The title displayed within the app will be something like: `Frequent 'android' Questions - Stack Overflow` After this commit, the app will display the correct decoded title: `Frequent 'android' Questions - Stack Overflow`

Alternatively, scan this to replicate:
![http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/android](http://zxing.org/w/chart?cht=qr&chs=120x120&chld=L&choe=UTF-8&chl=http%3A%2F%2Fstackoverflow.com%2Fquestions%2Ftagged%2Fandroid)

title: Multibyte characters are not handled properly in PDF417 encoder
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Trying to encode the string "1%§s ?aG$" with PDF417 encoder (Charset UTF-8, Compaction Byte) throw a "Non-encodable character detected" exception.

The problem seems to be that § is encoded as "c2 a7" in unicode and thus for all characters after the § the index in the input-string does not match the index in the encoded byte array.

title: Use result metadata to return Code39 Full-ASCII decoded value and checksum status
body:
The proposed change will:
- attempt to decode Code39 in Full-ASCII form, and if successful will return it as a result meta-data.
- attempt to calculate the checksum and return the state as a result meta-data
- display the Code39 Full-ASCII result in the Android scanner screen

TODO:
- Handle codes that have a checksum and are encoded using the Code39 Full-ASCII form

title: Add a prefix to Maven artifacts
body:
Perhaps in the next major version you could add a prefix to the maven artifact names so that the jars get a decent name in non-library upstream projects (ie WAR)?

Right now the jars will have the nondescript and confusing names of `core-x.x.x.jar` and `javase-x.x.x.jar` in a canonical Maven WAR. The ostensible industry standard seems to be to prefix your artifact names with the project name.

``` xml
<dependency>
    <groupId>com.google.zxing</groupId>
    <artifactId>zxing-core</artifactId>
    <version>3.2.0</version>
</dependency>
```

There are of course work-arounds (such as never name any of your artifacts `core` or configure: http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-war-plugin/examples/file-name-mapping.html )  so I understand if this bug/encancement is considered trivial or not really worth doing.

title: splitQuery ignore characters
body:
Test Name: splitQuery Unit Test Version: 1.0

Severity (Fatal, Serious, Minor): Minor

Type: (Coding Error, Design Issue, Suggestion, Documentation): Coding Error

Summary: Method should get rid of repeated specific characters, but it do not. 

Able to be reproduced? (Yes/No): Yes

What is the problem and how can it be reproduced?
The Javadoc for the method splitQuery, inside class DecodeHintManager, states that the method should ignore repeated specific characters, such as double ampersands, using only the first one. After unit tests, we find out that it although it ignores the repeated characters, the final result will be different as if you had only a single specific character.

title: Fixed the cameraId changing on powerbutton press
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
When using the QR code reader with a front facing camera (non-default camera) if you turn the screen off and on (pressing power button) the camera being used changes to the default camera. This occurs because when the screen is turned off and on the surfaceView is not destroyed causing a different  behavior in CaptureActivity.onResume(). The surfaceView not being destroyed causes the CameraManager to open the camera before setting the cameraId. This pull request has reordered these operations to make sure the manual setting of cameraId inside CaptureActivity.onResume() occurs before the CameraManager opening the camera.

For more information see the following post:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/zxing/CguxsAm0SjE

title: Data Matrix Rectangular Extension
body:
I added the pull request https://github.com/zxing/zxing/pull/323 with my work on support for DMRE as described in http://www.aim-d.de/images/stories/pdfs/Arbeitskreise/Barcode/aim_spec_dmre_2014-09-22.pdf

It is functional enough for my needs, but I think it needs at least a good look from a maintainer before proper inclusion into zxing.

title: Support for Data Matrix Rectangular Extensions
body:
This is a functional (but not clean) implementation of Data Matrix Rectangular Extensions as defined in the specification http://www.aim-d.de/images/stories/pdfs/Arbeitskreise/Barcode/aim_spec_dmre_2014-09-22.pdf

The implementation is divided in 3 separate commits:

https://github.com/zxing/zxing/commit/c815a4babb3708f1ae3e1115bb5dbb61d50cd4b8:
This adds the rectangles to the datamatrix definition tables.

https://github.com/zxing/zxing/commit/f2a32a45f053215175fa6750a006106b44a0705a:
This changes the threshold for determining a rectangular datamatrix form. This is necessary, because the old threshold excluded some of the new rectangles. It has the side effect of test failures in the datamatrix code, but AFAICS it has no effect on the functionality itself.

https://github.com/zxing/zxing/commit/e6713ae554c44fb158e49e7139a5441165db71af:
Some of the new forms resulted in an ArrayOutOfBoundsException. As I am not able to fix this cleanly I implemented this worlaround. The Exception may probably be fixed easily by a developer with more in-depth knowledge...

title: Fixes Github Issue #314
body:
Instead of using the request code as a parameter, preserves the previous api of `parseActivityResult()` and delegates its implementation to a new `parseActivityResult()` which adds a boolean parameter to determine whether to use the static (hardcoded) REQUEST_CODE, if such parameter is true, it behaves as before, if it false it doesn't check against the request code.

A better alternative would be to honor original `parseActivityResult`'s `requestCode` in the code, but it would require a change in the API.

title: Make IntentIntegrator REQUEST_CODE parametrizable
body:
The current implementation of `initiateScan()` uses a fixed request code when calling `startActivityForResult(...)`, which could be bypassed by calling `createIntent()` and starting the intent activity externally. 

But `parseActivityResult()` cannot be bypassed, because REQUEST_CODE is hardwired in the code.

It would be desirable to have a version of `initiateScan()` and `parseActivityResult()` that receives the request code as argument.

title: A small correction on Spanish translation
body:
According to the DRAE (Dictionary of the Spanish language by the Spanish Royal Academy), there's no noun derived from "escáner" (scanner) that represents the act of scanning something. So, taking into account the original sentence in English: "No barcode scans have been recorded", I think a more appropriate translation would be "Ninguna lectura de código de barras se ha registrado aún", which uses the word "lectura" (read - as the act of reading something) instead.
Please, also notice a fix on agreement.

title: URL truncated after vertical bar ("|")
body:
Steps to reproduce:

Expected behavior: 
You should be able to visit the full web address (which includes a vertical bar): http://www.cofchrist.org/events?tags=organ-recital|dome-and-spire

Actual behavior: 
The URL is cut short at the vertical bar ("|") and it takes you to http://www.cofchrist.org/events?tags=organ-recital instead.

title: Scan via browser URL seems to cache redirect and return to wrong location
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="bug")]
body:
I have developed a simple web app we use for tracking boxes at work which updates a database.

The boxes all have barcodes attached.

This is somewhat simplified, but for the purposes of this bug report I have two pages in the web app:
- Look up a box
- Add a new box

On the "add a new box" page I have a button which links to Barcode Scanner with a URL like:
http://zxing.appspot.com/scan?ret=https%3A%2F%2Fmyserver.example.com%2Faddbox.php%3F%26xid%3D%7BCODE%7D

On the "look up a box" page I have a similar button but it links to a different URL:
http://zxing.appspot.com/scan?ret=https%3A%2F%2Fmyserver.example.com%2Flookupbox.php%3F%26xid%3D%7BCODE%7D

However, I find if I go to "add a new box", scan a barcode with a particular value (doesn't seem to matter what type of barcode, I've reproduced with code 128 and with QR code), I am redirected correctly. But if I later go to "look up a box" and scan the same barcode, it returns me to addbox.php not lookupbox.php even though the link on the "look up a box" page was definitely correct.

If I scan a different barcode on the "look up a box" page I'm correctly redirected to lookupbox.php. If I clear all zxing's app data, and go to the "look up a box" page, and scan the same barcode, I'm also correctly redirected to lookupbox.php.

It looks like zxing is somehow caching the ret= value along with a particular barcode and refusing to change it on a later scan of the same code.

This breaks my web app's functionality. I guess the only way I can really work around it is by redirecting all scans to the same scan.php page and then using PHP session variables or something to tell scan.php where I really want to be redirected to. This is, quite obviously, a pain.

I'm using Barcode Scanner version 4.7.0 on a Sony Xperia Z2 running Android 4.4.4.

title: DataMatrixWriter generates wrong BitMatrix
body:
When trying to encode the string "_DTCP01" (without quotes), the DataMatrixWriter delivers a wrong BitMatrix. The BitMatrix represents the string "_DTCP04 47" (without quotes).

The issue is easy to reproduce with the given string. Other examples work.

This is actually a very annoying issue, since the reason for the behavior is not clear. Seems to be somehow related to the leading asterix.

Remark:
Barcode4j has the same issue. IText's BarcodeDatamatrix renders the barcode as expected.
As far as I understood the zxing package history, the DataMatrix implementation is based on Barcode4j - so maybe this is an inherited issue.

title: GS1 - code 128 barcodes, FNC1 character is suppressed.
body:
We use this in ZXING in with our data collection applications for warehouse logistics.
Often we scan barcodes that conform to the GS1 standard, that contain multiple fields.
For variable length fields, a FNC1 character (ascii 29) is used as a terminator.
For 1D Code128 formated barcodes, the FNC1 character is suppressed.

title: GS1 - code 128 barcodes, FNC1 character is suppressed.
Android 2.2 NoSuchMethodError: java.lang.String.isEmpty
body:
Using Android 2.2 I get an error.

``` java
MultiFormatWriter writer = new MultiFormatWriter();
> BitMatrix result = writer.encode( contentsToEncode, BarcodeFormat.CODE_128, img_width, img_height, null ); <
```

``` log
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: java.lang.String.isEmpty
    at com.google.zxing.oned.OneDimensionalCodeWriter.encode(OneDimensionalCodeWriter.java:53)
    at com.google.zxing.oned.Code128Writer.encode(Code128Writer.java:61)
    at com.google.zxing.MultiFormatWriter.encode(MultiFormatWriter.java:94)
```

The method isEmpty was added in Android 2.3 (API 9)
See more here http://developer.android.com/reference/java/lang/String.html#isEmpty()

title: Revert "Fix PDF417 numeric encoding grouping index check"
using initiateScan() in android.support.v4.app.Fragment is not invoking onActivityResult()
body:
I tried the following inside the android.support.v4.app.Fragment:

``` java
 IntentIntegrator integrator = new IntentIntegrator(getActivity());
```

The constructor for the Fragment is only available for the native Fragment provided by the SDK in the device not the support-v4 or package.
After deeper investigation i find out that the REQUEST_CODE:
https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/6c522f127a0ac40b2e14518528c9547018e044b2/android-integration/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/integration/android/IntentIntegrator.java#L112

value seems the issue. It prevents later in the FragmentActivity here:
http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/ext/com.google.android/android/5.0.0_r1/android/support/v4/app/FragmentActivity.java/#150
that the index is not 0. Then it traverses through all fragments and invokes onActivityResult() properly.
I set a breakpoint with the debugger and modified the REQUEST_CODE and it works. I haven't tested it if this implies other problems.

Would be nice to have your feedback. Thank you very much for reading.

title: Add info to the README about active C++ port and Ruby bindings
body:
I forked the old deleted C++ code into it's own [light-weight repo](https://github.com/glassechidna/zxing-cpp), as I wanted to build some [regular Ruby (not JRuby) bindings](https://github.com/glassechidna/zxing_cpp.rb).

The Ruby bindings are actually just a fork of [Steven's Ruby bindings](https://github.com/smparkes/zxing.rb), where I've mostly just removed all the JRuby and MacRuby bits and then added all the stuff necessary to package and publish a [zxing_cpp gem](http://rubygems.org/gems/zxing_cpp).

Anyway, this commit just adds some info about the projects to the README so people looking for an active C++ port and some Ruby bindings can find them.

title: datamatrix dimensions

title: Bad XML Block on Android device
qrcode margin increases when content increases and eventually the qrcode shrinks in size.
body:
This is a weird issue. When the content for vCard increases, the margin around qrcode increases.
In my code I am setting 'MARGIN' to 0 in 'com.google.zxing.EncodeHintType' and this is how I want it.
But what I noticed was that if the name name is long, then the qrcode strinks in size. I need the qrcode to be of 300 x 300 size. 

I am generating these qrcode using MRI ruby 2.1.1 with zxing/core jar in a Rails(v 4.1.0) web app.
ATM i am using an older version(not sure which version) but I have tried with version 3.1.0 and I am getting the same result.

Below are some sample I have generated with my code and older version of core jar. Notice the 3rd qrcode is smaller even though all images are of  same size.
Does anyone know a fix to this issue. Please help me out here.

title: Ability to disable history saving
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
A hopefully quick, easy one. I use Barcode Scanner with an alarm clock app to scan a bar code and return its contents to the alarm clock app, which decides whether or not the scanned Barcode is the one required to disable the alarm. However once I have scanned the Barcode a single time, it appears in the History section and allows me to click it and return the Barcode's contents to the alarm app without actually having scanned the code, therefore defeating the point of the app (getting out of bed to scan the code). 

So the issue boils down to: can there be a way to implement the disabling of Barcode history in the app, so lazy people like me can get up in the morning? Many thanks indeed.

title: Code 128 scan at an angle return a UPC-E with different value
body:
Good day

When I scan a Code 128 barcode and rotate the scanner a bit the value returned is different than the actual barcode value.

About 1% to 2% of the scans returned invalid value.
I scan a Code 128 barcode with a value of 4001599 and the following returned on a good scan:

result.text=4001599 
result-format=CODE_128 
result.cancelled=false

Then when the scan is not 100% in the window or a bit at an angle I get the following result on the same barcode.

result.text=18112146 
result.format=UPC_E 
result.cancelled=false 

My conclusion is that the UPC_E does not calculate a check digit.
Sometimes the scan only capture a part of the barcode and interpret it as a UPC-E barcode.

Is there any possibility for this to get fixed?

Admittedly a useless feature to be able to share a [running man in QR](https://zxing.googlecode.com/issues/attachment?aid=3663283145157266909&name=QRanimation.jpg&token=ABZ6GAcLhEZ-C2_tpqxjPFKZKdfNJN27Wg%3A1412313599109&inline=1), but that doesn't mean I don't want to be able to do it. :D

So somehow recognize that http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_URI_scheme is valid, and can be opened in android from the "browser scanner"

---

Alternatively you can try adding support for actual binary content. Either way works (but probably more space efficient with direct binary)

title: "Structured Append" in QR
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Just noticed that QR has support for splitting a text (and hopefully binary file as well) into multiple QR codes that can be scanned sequentially to reconstruct the file.

This might be useful. How hard would it be to support this?

---

src: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12905485/storing-a-bmp-image-in-a-qr-code

> The best source of information you can use is the norm about QR Codes (ISO 18004:2006); it's possible (but not necessarily easy) to find it for free on the web.
> 
> The relevant part (section 9) of this norm says:
> 
> > "Up to 16 QR Code symbols may be appended in a structured format. If a symbol is part of a Structured Append message, it is indicated by a header block in the first three symbol character positions. The Structured Append Mode Indicator 0011 is placed in the four most significant bit positions in the first symbol character. This is immediately followed by two Structured Append codewords, spread over the four least significant bits of the first symbol character, the second symbol character and the four most significant bits of the third symbol character. The first codeword is the symbol sequence indicator. The second codeword is the parity data and is identical in all symbols in the message, enabling it to be verified that all symbols read form part of the same Structured Append message. This header is immediately followed by the data codewords for the symbol commencing with the first Mode Indicator."

---

http://www.onbarcode.com/qr_code/structured_append/

> Structured AppendBasic principles 
> 
> Structured append cannot be used in Micro QR Code. 
> 
> One QR Code 2005 symbol can be divided into up to 16 symbols. On the contrary, it can be appended into a structured format. If a symbol is a part of the structured append message, it can be represented by a header block in the first two and a half character positions The four most significant bit positions of the first symbol character set the Structured Append mode indicator 0011. 
> 
> In Structured Append mode, two Structured Append codewords follows indicators, which are placed in the four least significant bits position of the first symbol character, the eight bit position of the second symbol character and the four most significant bit position of the third symbol character respectively. The first codeword is symbol sequence indicator, the second one is parity data, which is identical in all append message to enable all readable symbols are part of the same Structured Append message. This header is followed by the data symbols commencing with the indicator of the first mode. If adopted other ECI mode rather than ECI default mode, each header block consisting of ECI indicator and ECI designator should follow Structured Append header.

title: ByQuadrantReader only throws NotFoundExceptions
body:
Hello!

I'm scanning multiple PDF417 codes on one image. Works fine this way:

```
 greader = new GenericMultipleBarcodeReader((reader));
```

The reader passed here is a PDF417Reader. I only get 82 NotFoundExceptions out of a total of 2592 images.

However, if I use the ByQuadrantReader like this:

```
 greader = new GenericMultipleBarcodeReader((new ByQuadrantReader(reader)));
```

I only get NotFoundExceptions. The reader still is a PDF417Reader.

Why is that? Do I have to change anything else in the the code?

title: code128c doesn't write checksum
body:
Given the following:

``` scala
    val writer = new MultiFormatWriter()
    val matrix = writer.encode("123456789", BarcodeFormat.CODE_128, 400, 100)
    val out = new ByteArrayOutputStream()
    MatrixToImageWriter.writeToStream(matrix, "PNG", out)
    out.toByteArray
```

The outputted barcode doesn't contain the checksum. Once scanned back in the checksum doesn't appear.

In fact this might be as simple as the checksum is not meant to appear.

title: Feature request: GS1-128 parser/decoder
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Hello,
the barcode scanner app is a great tool! Thank you very much. 
One additional feature would make it perfect for me. Namely this is a GS1-128 parser that decodes the content/data of the barcode. GS1-128 was formerly named EAN-128 or CCG-128. 
For instance from the barcode data "3103123456107890" it gives as result 
- Netweight: 123,456 kg
- Lot: 7890

Such a feature would be helpfull for testing/reading transportation labels in a lot of logistics purposes, especially for foods. Some time ago I found a good example implementation here: 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5685964/decoding-ean-128
Unfortunately I am not so familiar with programming java. It would be great if one of you guys will find it interessting and usefull, too.

Best regards,
Praktifix

title: ByQuadrantReader - QRCode ResultPoint coordinate
body:
Hi,
I understand QRCodeMultiReader().decodeMultiple scans the entire image trying to find QRCode and it usually fails when there are multiple QRCodes close to each other.  However, whenever it does detect a QRCode, it will report the absolute image coordinate in the ResultPoints.

ByQuadrantReader does a much better job of detecting multiple QRCodes in an image, but ResultPoints appears to be relative to the quadrant instead of to the image.  Is there a way for ByQuadrantReader to provide the absolute image coordinate in ResultPoints?

For example:
QRCodeMultiReader().decodeMultiple would give:
"MyQRCodeText"
(746.5,634.5)
(744.5,549)
(835.0,545.5)

ByQuadrantReader  would give:
"MyQRCodeText"
(746.5,274.5)
(744.5,189.5)
(835.0,185.16667)

title: mailto: should handle CC & BCC
body:
As per https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24878382/matmsg-mailto-qr-code-cc-bcc-fields/24891392#comment38668862_24891392

A QR code containing a mailto: link may contain CC & BCC fields 

`mailto:recipient@example.com?cc=other@example.com&subject=hello`

Relevant RFC: http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6068#section-6

This will require changes to 
- https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/client/result/EmailAddressParsedResult.java
- https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/client/result/EmailAddressParsedResult.java
- https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/29eeee8ccdcf5db70d786983f5eae333a50adc33/android/src/com/google/zxing/client/android/result/EmailAddressResultHandler.java

title: Raw domains rejected despite Google Android Support standard
body:
Hello - I've been using this plugin very happily, but discovered a problem which might well force me to use another product. 

If a valid URL such as 
http://xx.xx.xxx.xx
is entered (with valip ip address numbers instead of x's of course)

zxing says it is a "bad URL" and wont resolve _if the file is opened raw within Chrome_ 
In other words, if the gif is in a frame on the page (such as in this bug report) the plugin will read it fine, but if it is only the file in the browser tab, the plugin will fail by declaring a bad url.

However, the exact same qr code is scannable without issue by Android's default scanner for my phone, the "Barcode Scanner" app specifically. I have attached an example gif.

title: ZXing android decoder : GB2312 string
body:
I haven't seen your source code, but I guess there're some issues on reading Chinese.
According to GB/T 18284—2000 specification, in Chinese Hanzi (GB) mode 1101,we should put sub-charset indicator 0001 which represent GB2312. I am sure your source code has put it because ZXing android can read my barcode. But if I mixed some Japanese which including in GB2312 table,ZXing failed to read those Japanese characters but can read Chinese. I guess your decoder has a wrong GB2312 First byte range.

According to GB/T 18284—2000, the GB2312 Range is:
First Byte : &HA1-&HF7 and second byte:&HA1-&HFE

This exactly match GB2312 table （http://ash.jp/code/cn/gb2312tbl.htm）

'---------------------------------------------------------------------
The string to encode is : インドネシア,韩国有句俗语：三个铜板买房屋，千两黄金买邻居。インドネシア

ZXing Android application Read:韩国有句俗语：三个铜板买房屋，千两黄金买邻居。

you cab see ZXing decoder ignore front and backwrad Japanese which incuded in GB2312 table.

title: Support the SPAYD format for the payment information exchange
body:
Since December 2012, the QR code payments are standardized in the Czech Republic via the SPAYD format. The format is used with all local banks, all local invoicing software and almost all large invoice issuers, and it is applicable across the whole Europe. It would be nice to integrate the SPAYD support in the default ZXing scanner.

For more info about SPAYD, see:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short_Payment_Descriptor
https://github.com/spayd/spayd-java
https://github.com/inmite/spayd-sdk

title: Enhancement - A HTTP service mode for zxing for better integration with websites.
body:
I really like the your zxing app and wanted to suggest this. Happy to program the Android/Javascript part of it if people are interested.

A HTTP service mode for zxing.
For better integration with websites.

Process:
1. User visits webapp/webpage.
2. App checks for xzing http sever.
3. Is the server running? If not, prompt to install, or open using intent URL that triggers the service to start.
4. zxing http server now running.
5. User clicks on "scan barcode" button.
6. Http requests are made every second to the zxing server url (ie http://localhost:8080).
7. The server returns two things:
    a. base64 encoded image of what the camera is seeing at that point
    b. the captured barcode data (returned once for every barcode recognition).
8. The javascript app show a small dialog to display the base64 image data and has a button to stop the barcode recognition.
9. A callback is issued every time a barcode is received.

This would produce seamless integration for web-apps :-D

Please let me know what you think.

Open links with non-http(s) scheme
body:
When scanning a barcode containing a link that doesn't have http(s) as scheme, only the host:port/path portion is recognized as link and clickable, e.g.:

QR code contains: opc.tcp://test.samplehost.com:4841
Clickable link: test.samplehost.com:4841

We're developing an Android application that has the opc.tcp scheme registered and would open if a link was clicked with the opc.tcp scheme. Using Barcode Scanner this is not possible, as it opens test.samplehost.com:4841 in the browser. Please improve the URL parser to detect non-http(s) schemes and allow to click them.

Cheers!

title: PDF Barcode generation giving strange results
body:
Platform: Android 4.0+
Zxing Version: 3.0.1
Barcode Format: PDF417

Since CP437 encoding isn't present on Android I've tried setting different encodings to render a PDF417 barcode but it is prepending extra characters that vary based on the encoding.

US-ASCII
Prepends with 'A'

ISO-8859-1
Prepends with 'AB'

UTF-8
Prepends with 'A\s'

UTF16 prepends stranger characters and actually loses a character from the original source.

Using the following to set the Character set
hints.put(EncodeHintType.CHARACTER_SET, "US-ASCII");

Is there anyway to prevent the rendered barcode from prefixing these characters?

title: Update strings.xml

title: Implement executing scanned code directly as binaries
body:
QR codes, data as they are, are never meant to be executed as if they were programs. Yet most 2D bar codes are capable to encrypt enough information to be a program that could be executed in given platform themselves. All bar code readers should only be given `read` permission. But if a user accidentally given `all permissions` to the bar code reader in his/her device, and later on, scanned a 2D bar code that encrypted binary code targeted at his/her device that exploits system vulnerabilities, that could be worse than anything else.

Is there a way to stop this? Stopping people from encoding programs into bar codes is impractical. But can you also control users and their system so that the reader _never_ gets the permission to execute?

---

com.google.zxing.pdf417.decoder.PDF417ScanningDecoder : java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: length=7; index=7

Note that this does not seem to be the same problem as in issue #67, because that problem has already been fixed in core library version 3.0.1. Also the stack trace is different.

title: Replaced switch statements with if statements so you can create a library

title: Thread-safe lazy initialization in GenericGF
body:
This pull request is an attempt to fix the following exception which is reported multiple times per day from an Android app that I work on:

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Divide by 0
       at com.google.zxing.common.reedsolomon.GenericGFPoly.divide(SourceFile:205)
       at com.google.zxing.common.reedsolomon.ReedSolomonEncoder.encode(SourceFile:65)
       at com.google.zxing.qrcode.encoder.Encoder.generateECBytes(SourceFile:436)
       at com.google.zxing.qrcode.encoder.Encoder.interleaveWithECBytes(SourceFile:391)
       at com.google.zxing.qrcode.encoder.Encoder.encode(SourceFile:144)
       at com.google.zxing.qrcode.encoder.Encoder.encode(SourceFile:76)
...
```

The `initialized` field was not thread-safe which allowed multiple threads to call `initialize()`. This concurrent re-initialization would potentially allow mutations to be observed in `expTable` and `logTable` during encoding operations. Even if re-initialization did not occur, there is no guarantee that the initialization of these tables is visible on other threads because those initializing mutations occur outside of a synchronized context. Adding a double-checked lock and a nested holder class ensures that these shared resources are initialized once, visible to all threads, and never change.

I spent a while reviewing the code and came to the conclusion that this is the only possible explanation for the exception above. I was also able to generate corrupt `QRCode`s quite frequently due to this issue. That problem should also be addressed by this fix.

title: Updates for XE16 compatibility.
body:
XE16 was released in April 2014 and replaced XE12 from December 2013.  XE16 changes the way voice triggers are set up.  They now require a permission in the manifest and use a different trigger syntax.

I also changed the trigger to be more relevant for zxing.

I tested this on Glass and it works.

title: PDF417 decodes the character ']' incorrectly as '}'
Support for WPA-Enterprise?
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Hello

We just stumbled upon the problem that we want to grand our members (4k+) access to our distributed wifi network which uses 802.1X for authentication.
Currently the scanner supports only "open","WEP", "WPA" and "WPA2".

According to my current understanding of the code (if I missed something please tell me) there are only the files 

core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/client/result/WifiResultParser.java
core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/client/result/WifiParsedResult.java

which generate the config and is parsed to the Android manager later. According to the Android documentation the WifiConfiguration accepts "public WifiEnterpriseConfig enterpriseConfig" with all neccessary sub-options like "public int getPhase2Method ()" etc. However testing in our network (with it's current configuration) using an QR-Code was not successful. 

Am I wrong? If yes I would like to know where my mistake is.
If you need further information in order to reproduce the issue don't hesitate to contact me.

Greetings
Michael

title: Problems with QRCode scanning on a Sony Xperia Z1
body:
Hi,

we are currently using ZXing 2.3.0 in our project to integrate a QRCode scanner. The scanning works fine on all Android devices except of the Sony Xperia Z1. Here it takes several attempts to scan a QRCode. 

To eliminate some implementation mistakes we also tried out the ZXing Test scanning application provided by your team and we try around with the provided settings - but without any success. Last we tried to use the newest release version (3.0.0) also without feeling any improvements.

Are there any known issues with this mobile / ZXIng constellation? Maybe the problem is the huge amount of megapixel (20,7). Currently Android version 4.3 is installed on our Sony Xperia Z1 mobile.

Or is there any other approach to get it working on this device?

Cheers
Dennis

title: Add ability to select camera when integrating via intent
body:
Please make the SCAN activity accept camera requests from the intent.
So that when another app calls zxing via IntentIntegrator, it could request a particular camera to recognize barcodes from, as opposed to the default camera picked by zxing.

title: Add year and owner to COPYING
body:
The [COPYING](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/COPYING) file in line 189 contains the following:

```
   Copyright [yyyy] [name of copyright owner]
```

This is probably an oversight and should be updated.

title: Wrong EAN13 code detected - am I doing something wrong?
body:
![why](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/181293/2775177/b3bd1e44-cac2-11e3-8200-766268c572f4.png)

The above-attached image is wrongly detected - I used:

```
wget https://github.com/zxing/zxing/archive/master.zip
unzip master.zip
cd zxing-master/
mvn compile
cd javase/target/classes/
java -cp .:../../../core/target/classes com/google/zxing/client/j2se/CommandLineRunner why.png --try_harder  --pure_barcode
```

...which prints a wrong number (compare to that in the image):

```
Raw result:
000642109420
Parsed result:
000642109420
Found 2 result points.
  Point 0: (78.5,64.0)
  Point 1: (335.5,64.0)
```

Am I doing something wrong, or is this kind of errors something to be expected when trying to detect barcodes?

P.S. In case it helps, the barcode was generated inside a Jasper Report, with the Barbeque library, and the document was then scanned back.

title: No Autofocus on Samsung Galaxy S3 and S4
body:
We just received a report from one of our users reporting this problem for the Samsung Galaxy S4 and a colleague of mine demonstrated this problem on his Samsung Galaxy S3 app.

For those users, their phones are not even trying to autofocus on the barcode with default-settings in zxing.

I was able to workaround this problem by unchecking the checkbox "No continuous focus" in the zxing-settings page and recommended this workaround to users who reported this problem. I also initiated an updated description of our apps' playstore-page to notify new users about this.

As both S3 and S4 are very popular smartphones among our users, would it be possible to auto-apply this setting to those devices during init of camera-preview?
Or to show a message via toast or Dialog to users that have issues without autofocus?
Maybe this could be detected by measuring how long the camera-preview is open and if open longer than 10 seconds, show a toast-message to the user hinting at the settings?

Or maybe there is a better solution?

Thank you for your support!

Do you happen to know if zxing has already been used in an FDA-approved medical mobile app? If so, I would be grateful for a reference to the product and its use of zxing. Thanks.

title: Avoid requiring Charset Cp437 until absolutely necessary
body:
See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22706625/unsupportedcharsetexception-cp437-after-zxing-update/

Since Android does not have the `Cp437` charset, or at least it doesn't in some versions, it is important to avoid `Charset.forName("Cp437")` until really necessary. Encoding, for example, PDF417 will still fail if this charset is used, but not all PDF417 encoding modes use it.

Also, it should try the alternate name `IBM437` for the charset.

title: Try to re-add fragment support
Android - Fragment Support
body:
Hi Sean

Currently your android implementation (IntentIntegrator) takes an Activity as an argument and it's startActivityForResult() method is called on the Activity you pass it. This is fine when it's that activity calling the scanning intent, but becomes a bit messy when calling the scanner from a fragment. The resulting onActivityResult() call is handled first by the Activity, as per the android activity lifecycle. (Activity.startActivityForResult()...)

In my case, the Activity is housing multiple Fragments and it's a bit messy when passing down the results.

My question is this: Is there a way to call and return on a fragment in the existing codebase? I stumbled on code by Lachezars in 2012 which was removed from trunk that supported V4 fragments. It's basically just a wrapper that overrides startActivityForResult() and I updated it to handle android.app.Fragment. Is this perhaps the correct thing to do, or should i leave it alone to avoid copyright issues?

I have gone through the google discussion held in 2012, but i'm worried the code being removed from trunk might indicate i'm missing something for current fragment support.

Reference: 

IntentIntegratorSupportV4 https://code.google.com/p/zxing/source/browse/trunk/android-integration/src/com/google/zxing/integration/android/IntentIntegratorSupportV4.java?r=2122

Old Google Discussion
https://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1323

PS: Thanks for the great support on ZXing. Definitely my favorite barcode app. I've been reading your comments on multiple sites about integration vs intent/separate app. While i'm not too happy having a 2nd app requirement, I understand and respect your reasoning and have implemented it as per your preference. Keep up the great work.

title: Is it possible to reduce the quiet zone required for QR code decoding?
body:
Hello,

I am using zxing on an embedded system for recognizing QR codes on a surface (like thousands of codes on a piece of paper).
I need to reduce the quiet zone, so that I can increase drastically the precision of the device (the more QR codes I can put in a certain area, the better).

So, I reduced the MARGIN to 1 (0 seemed impossible to use as I know that zxing uses the quiet zone to define the QR code.
But I also noticed an extremely decrease in performance.

I was wondering, having a very small QR code (right now using around 100x100px), is shouldn't matter that much. The quiet zone is surely larger than anything in the code, so its recognition shouldn't be a problem.

Is there a way for me to reduce the 'standard' quiet zone (4) for decoding to something smaller, say 1?

title: Code39 - problems with vertical lines near the barcode margin
body:
Hi all,
first of all, thank you for the good work: the zxing library is nearly perfect, but I've had strange issues when trying to decode a barcode placed near vertical lines which, I guess, mimick another character of the barcode.
So, the barcode is not recognized at all.
I'v tried other product (i.e., JavaBar) and it recognizes the barcode without any problem.
I attach a sample image.

title: Validation for custom search URL fails
body:
The validation code for the custom search URL in PreferencesFragment seems to pass the user input to the URL class without removing the placeholders (%s etc).
Unfortunately this seems to yield a syntax error on KitKat as %s is not a valid escape code and thus prevents the use of a custom search URL.
If I replace the % with %25 (escaped %) the URL is accepted but the Barcode contents does not get inserted.
Test case: KitKat on Galaxy S4
URL rejected: https://www.google.com/search?q=%s
URL accepted but not working: https://www.google.com/search?q=%25s

Inserting the rejected URL directly into the preferences file (as root) works as expected.

Possible solution: Substitution of the placeholders with an empty string prior to the validation.

Maybe there's a way to set the scannable area (I know it looks for the barcode from the camera's center out). 

Any help would be much appreciated. Thanks in advance.

title: Possible  ReedSolomon decoding problem
Specify allowed EAN extensions as a hint
body:
Related to this question:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8544503/zxing-scanning-barcode-with-upc-5-supplemental

The use case is an application that needs to scan EAN-13 + EAN-5 barcodes, optionally also needing to allow other formats (e.g. QR codes), but not EAN-13 by itself.

The actual decoding of EAN-5 works perfectly. The problem is that most of the time, the barcode scanner picks up the normal EAN-13 part before it found the EAN-5 extension, and returns only that. I've also found that it sometimes only returns the first two characters, as if it was an EAN-2 extension.

This change allows you to specify a hint to not return any EAN/UPC barcode, unless it found an extension of the specified length (EAN-2, EAN-5 or both).

This is the least obtrusive way I've found to allow scanning of EAN-13 + EAN-5 barcodes, while still allowing it to be used with other formats in MultiFormatReader.

An alternative and slightly more flexible solution would be to add formats like EAN_13_WITH_EAN_5, but there are no many combinations to make this practical.

title: Support for Code B FNC characters
body:
I have a need to generate FNC characters for a scanner we are using. Previously the Code128Writer would crash for FNC characters, even though they were allowed in the input string. It correctly would set Code B, but if one of the ESCAPE_FNC_\* characters were present, it would crash with an ArrayOutOfBoundsException since the escape characters were not in the mapping array. I've added the mapping to the correct Code B characters.

Unless I'm missing something there aren't any lot of tests around Code128Writer. I've added a test case and exercised the Code B code. It's not exhaustive but it tests my use case. I'd appreciate direction on what should be tested here - my knowledge of barcodes is pretty much the Wikipedia article.

WhiteRectangleDetector and high-resolution images
body:
Hi,

With high resolution images, the WhiteRectangleDetector is detecting white rectangles INSIDE DataMatrix barcodes.

A possible solution would be to make INIT_SIZE a variable, and base the value on the overall dimensions of the image.

If that is not feasible, maybe you could make the value settable somehow from a Reader or DataMatrixReader.

Thanks for all your work creating and maintaining this project!

Regards,
Todd Gibson

Invalid UPC_E leads to StringIndexOutOfBoundsException in ResultParser.parseResult
body:
I get several stack like the following:
01-23 22:10:43.724: E/AndroidRuntime(28903): java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: length=1; regionStart=1; regionLength=6
01-23 22:10:43.724: E/AndroidRuntime(28903):    at java.lang.String.startEndAndLength(String.java:593)
01-23 22:10:43.724: E/AndroidRuntime(28903):    at java.lang.String.getChars(String.java:902)
01-23 22:10:43.724: E/AndroidRuntime(28903):    at com.google.zxing.oned.UPCEReader.convertUPCEtoUPCA(UPCEReader.java:124)
01-23 22:10:43.724: E/AndroidRuntime(28903):    at com.google.zxing.client.result.ProductResultParser.parse(ProductResultParser.java:51)
01-23 22:10:43.724: E/AndroidRuntime(28903):    at com.google.zxing.client.result.ProductResultParser.parse(ProductResultParser.java:28)
01-23 22:10:43.724: E/AndroidRuntime(28903):    at com.google.zxing.client.result.ResultParser.parseResult(ResultParser.java:87)

While this stack comes from calling ResultParser.parseResult with an effectively invalid UPC_E (as it has only 1 char while I understand an UPC_E should have 8 chars), I also encountered an equivalent issue with a decoded UPC_E.

If it is expected to throy, I guess it should be handled at most in ResultParser.parseResult as this method should then try the next Parser.

title: Kindle Fire HDX camera orientation inverted
body:
Install BarcodeScanner-4.5.1.apk from the downloads section on a Kindle Fire HDX
Notice that the UI is properly oriented in landscape mode but the camera preview is inverted (up-side-down)

The UI should be properly oriented in landscape mode (as it is) but the camera preview should also be right-side-up.

This issue occurs whether the Kindle's "Auto-Rotate" feature is enabled or disabled.

![device-2014-01-15-101638](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/822522/1947259/d3ccbee4-8047-11e3-817a-8e33b5b6146b.png)

Ported from https://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1833

title: Feature Request: Add the ParsedResult as part of IntentResult
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
This applies to android-integration. Currently, IntentIntegrator#parseActivityResult returns an IntentResult, which has a getContents() method returning a String.

In a lot of use cases, this String is not very helpful - it has to be parsed using the appropriate ResultParser anyway. This can of course be done as follows (taking the example of WiFi result):

```
IntentResult scanResult = IntentIntegrator.parseActivityResult(requestCode, resultCode, data);
Result result = new Result(scanResult.getContents(), null, null, BarcodeFormat.QR_CODE);
WifiParsedResult parsedResult = (WifiParsedResult) WifiResultParser.parseResult(result);
```

However, this requires the addition of the core.jar as a dependency. It seems overkill to add a 500KB+ dependency just for parsing the result (particularly since the ability to parse the result is already present in the Barcode Scanner app itself). 

I was able to avoid this by copying the following files into my project and making minor modifications to eliminate all parsers except the WifiResultParser:
- BarcodeFormat.java
- MathUtils.java 
- ParsedResult.java
- ParsedResultType.java 
- Result.java
- ResultType.java
- ResultMetadataType.java
- ResultParser.java
- ResultPoint.java
- TextParsedResult.java
- WifiParsedResult.java
- WifiResultParser.java

But since this is a frequent requirement, I propose to enhance the IntentResult API to also include the ParsedResult itself - exposed as a getParsedResult() method. I realize this is pretty simple thing to do and I would have made the changes and issued a pull request myself. However, this calls for a decision to be made that is best left to the project authors:

How to deal with exposing the ParsedResult and sub-classes to an Android app that uses IntentIntegrator? 
- Would you move these classes to the android-integration module? This would require the Barcode Scanner app to include android-integration as a dependency.
- Would you rather move these files to a separate module and add this module as a dependency for both Barcode Scanner app and the android-integration module?

Ported from https://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1832

title: ITF wide bar width, bar wide to narrow ratio
body:
Hi,

in source file 

core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/oned/ITFReader.java on line 50 we have:

private static final int W = 3; // Pixel width of a wide line

in comment you write "Wikipedia is a great reference for Interleaved 2 of 5 information"
and on Wikipedia site we have: wide line (2.0 to 3.0 times the width of a narrow line).

I implement "Wide To Narrow Ratio" in my barcode generator

http://www.generatorkodowkreskowych.pl/en/itf-14/
http://www.generatorkodowkreskowych.pl/en/2of5-interleaved/

You can generate ITF codes with diffrent wide line width (2 to 3 times the width of a narrow line)

For PNG images you can use:

at scale 100% (narrow bar = 1) and WTNR in [2, 3]                     wide bar = 2,3
at scale 200% (narrow bar = 2) and WTNR in [2, 2.5, 3]                wide bar = 4,5,6
at scale 300% (narrow bar = 3) and WTNR in [2, 2.33, 2.66, 3]         wide bar = 6,7,8,9
at scale 400% (narrow bar = 4) and WTNR in [2, 2.25, 2,5, 2.75, 3.0 ] wide bar = 8,9,10,11,12

For PDF files you can use:

scale in range 80% to 200%, Wide To Narrow Ratio in range 2.00 to 3.00 with 0.01 step.

I make tests:

generate codes with Wide/Narrow = 2, and with Wide/Narrow = 2.5, and Wide/Narrow = 3
print codes and read with manual barcode reader Argox AS-8000.

Your barcode reader can not read ITF barcode with Wide To Narrow Ratio = 2,
but can read Code-39 with Wide To Narrow Ratio = [2,3].

I assume this information can help you to improve ITFReader.

Ported from https://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1831

The PDF417 decoder ignores ECI segments. Would be nice if it paid attention to reserved codewords 925-927 and reused the ECI stuff from QR codes.

title: TRY_HARDER mode should scan for QR codes at 45-degree rotations
body:
QR code scanning is notably weaker when the code is rotated 45 degrees (plus multiples of 90) due to the assumptions made by heuristics. TRY_HARDER mode could cause it to also try a rotation of 45 degrees, just for QR codes, to account for this.

Ported from https://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1284

We should see rendered margin in all square barcode types. Instead, only QR_CODE honors this hint type.

label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="enhancement")]

title: Implement Share Intent
label: [Label(name="android"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Most of the time I want to forward a scanned URL (or some other data) somewhere so I can later check it out, usually with a laptop. This is currently not that easy:
1. Scan a QR code URL
2. Barcode Scanner shows buttons to open browser, share with email or SMS

Have a Share UI element which shows all the apps registered for sharing

A workaround currently is to open the scanned link in the browser and select "Share Page" which gives the option to share the link with a multitude of apps, including email and SMS.

However, this requires many steps and is slow and inconvenient. In some cases the browser gets redirected to a mobile site making it impossible to share the original URL. Sometimes the browser can't even open the URL, or proceeds to download the content.

Ported from https://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1402

title: MECARD / vCard encoding should delimit fields
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Address / city / state / postal code and so on are supposed to be separated in MECARD and vCard, by comma and semicolon, respectively. The code right now doesn't break this down beyond an address field though, so isn't able to format accordingly. 

Ideally the online encoder would have separate fields for address components. And, in Android, would retrieve address elements independently. However I am not sure Android breaks this out either, not via Intent.

Ported from https://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1468

title: Need to handle onSurfaceChanged() in Barcode Scanner?
body:
A user reported this exception:

```
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Requested window android.os.BinderProxy@xxxxxxxx does not exist
```

In looking at possible causes I see that we may not be implementing onSurfaceChanged(), when it may be needed to handle rotations. This should cause the camera to re-init with a new surface. This may be one of those situations that never actually came up in practice but is still wrong.

Ported from https://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1363

This is a to-do reminder that PDF 417 really needs to finally implement error correction. It's not Reed-Solomon, quite. I will commit some pieces that will help so far but will have to work on this a while to understand and implement it.

title: Proposal for decoding of GS1 compliant datamatrix codes
body:
Hi together,

I often scan GS1 compliant datamatrix codes with zxing (which is lovely, btw.). Unfortunately they were not decoded into the different application identifiers (with their values).

I added a parser to decode and format the content. The major changes are in the core library. 
I'm a bit uncertain if decoding countries and currencies from the three digit iso codes is a good idea, as they are more or less likely to change.

If the code lacks of further tests or needs some tweaking to meet your quality standards, please let me know. Unfortunately I formatted the core\pom.xml what messed it up a bit in the diff :-(.

Cheers,

Melchior

PS: I noticed that your primary repo is a google svn. I don't have a google login (and it's not likely I'll have one in the future), so I'm not able to commit the patch there.

title: "BitMatrix to Bitmap"-Writer, to easily display generated QR-Codes in Android applications
body:
The javase module has a `MatrixToImageWriter` for creating displayable BufferedImages for Swing applications. The android-integration module misses this capability.

So, this is a "port" of the mentioned writer for Android, by using Androids `Bitmap`-class, instead of the (in Android not available) BufferedImage class.

By the way, the app name in Japanese was defined as "QRコードスキャナー" ("QR Code Scanner" in Japanese) in res/values-ja/strings.xml.
The second commit changes it to "Barcode Scanner". The third commit changes it to "バーコードスキャナー" ("Barcode Scanner" in Japanese).

If "QR Code Scanner" is your intention, I will rewrite the help pages. If you prefer "Barcode Scanner" but not "バーコードスキャナー", ignore the third commit.

title: Updated Finnish translation
Pdf417 merge
body:
The main changes are handling of ambiguous values, a few bug fixes, code cleanup, adding a Macro PDF417 test case and a few bits and pieces of documentation.

Regarding the new test case for Macro PDF417 decoding: It's a quick hack and in order to keep the changes in the common classes to a minimum, it copies a lot of code from other classes and methods. To avoid this, I'd have to make quite a few methods protected and non final and add a few hooks in AbstractBlackBoxTestCase . For the same reason I copied TestResult.java into the package. How do you feel about allowing subclasses more access to AbstractBlackBoxTestCase and TestResult?

Best regards,

  Guenther

P.S.: A short list of what changed:

BarcodeMatrix:
replaced by two dimensional array of BarcodeValue

BarcodeValue:
Added comments, handling ambiguous values

BoundingBox:
Improve calculation and handling

Codeword:
toString method

DetectionResult:
Improved row numbering
applying std code format
toString method

DetectionResultColumn:
improved method names
toString method

DetectionResultRowIndicatorColumn:
Improved row numbering
Improved support for partial RI columns and missing/and or damaged start- and stop pattern

PDF417ScanningDecoder:
Improved bounding box handling
Improved support for partial RI columns and missing/and or damaged start- and stop pattern
Improved handling ambiguous values

Detector:
No instance needed anymore
applying std code format
fix off by one error on bottom coordinate detection

PDF417Common:
More common constants
added util method

PDF417Reader
Use static Detector method instead of creating instance

pdf417-2/24.bin
correct expected result

pdf417-4/*
test images and results for Macro PDF417 decoding

PDF41BlackBox4TestCase:
test case for Macro PDF417 decoding

TestResult
Copy of common test result

PDF417BlackBoxTestCase
updated expected results

title: MSVC2010 support, enabled -ansi and -pedantic
body:
This is the promised patch for [Issue 1205](http://code.google.com/p/zxing/issues/detail?id=1205). What was changed:
- replaced some C99-ish allocations with std::vector
- added some defines for NAN, INFINITY, etc. (windows only)
- added win-iconv (windows only)
- some changes to SConscript to support MSVC
- some changes to SConscript for GCC (enabled -ansi and -pedantic to make gcc reject code that would also be rejected by msvc... as usual more or less...)

title: android-test and android-integration
body: Android test activity does not use the Intent Integrator method, so if barcode scanner is not installed it will just crash.  To alter this, I changed androidtest to use IntentIntegrator for scanning and sharing, where possible, and changed IntentIntegrator to allow bundles of extras to be passed.  Certain test items will still crash if barcode scanner is not installed, such as searching book contents, and other things which don't seem likely to be called via Intent.
